headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Autodesk Fourth Quarter Fiscal 2016 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to had a meeting over to David Gennarelli,
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Autodesk Fourth Quarter Fiscal 2016 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to had a meeting over to David Gennarelli, Senior Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, operator. Good afternoon. Thank you for joining our conference call to discuss the results of our fourth quarter and full year fiscal 2016. Also on the line is Carl Bass, our CEO; and Scott Herren, our CFO. Today's conference call is being broadca
componenttext:
Thanks, operator. Good afternoon. Thank you for joining our conference call to discuss the results of our fourth quarter and full year fiscal 2016. Also on the line is Carl Bass, our CEO; and Scott Herren, our CFO. Today's conference call is being broadcast live via webcast. In addition, a replay of this call will be available at autodesk.com/investor. As noted in our press release, we have published our prepared remarks and our website in advance of this call. Those remarks are intended to serve in place of extended formal comments and we will not repeat them at this call. 
During the course of this conference call, we will make forward-looking statements regarding future events and the anticipated future performance of the company, such as our guidance for the third quarter and full year fiscal 2017; our long-term financial model guidance; the factors we use to estimate our guidance, including currency headwinds; expectations regarding our restructuring; our transition to new business models; our market opportunities and strategies; and trends for various products, geographies and industries. We caution you that such statements reflect the best judgment based on factors currently known to us and that actual events or results could differ materially. Please refer to the documents we file from time to time with the SEC, specifically our Form 10-K for the fiscal year 2015; our Form 10-Q for the periods ended April 30, July 31 and October 31, 2015; and our current reports on Form 8-K, including the Form 8-K furnished with today's press release and prepared remarks. Those documents contain and identify important risks and other factors that may cause our actual results to differ from those contained in our forward-looking statements. Forward-looking statements made during the call are being made as of today. If this call is replayed or reviewed after today, the information presented during the call may not contain current or accurate information. Autodesk disclaims any obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements. We will provide guidance for today's call, but will not provide any further guidance or updates on our performance during the quarter unless we do so in a public forum. 
During the call, we will also discuss non-GAAP financial measures. These non-GAAP measures are not prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles. A reconciliation of our GAAP and non-GAAP results is provided in today's press release, prepared remarks and on the Investor Relations section of our website. We will quote a number of numeric or growth changes as we discuss our financial performance. And unless otherwise noted, each such reference represents a year-on-year comparison. 
And now I'd like to turn the call over to Carl.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave, and good afternoon, everyone. Let's start by wrapping up Q4. Then I want to take a few minutes to talk about long-term value creation for our shareholders, and then we'll leave guidance. As you saw in the press release, we had a terrific f
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave, and good afternoon, everyone. Let's start by wrapping up Q4. Then I want to take a few minutes to talk about long-term value creation for our shareholders, and then we'll leave guidance. 
As you saw in the press release, we had a terrific fourth quarter and our results demonstrated our business model transition is working. The end of the fourth quarter is marked with a key milestone and Autodesk transition to our software-as-a-service business as we hit the end of sale day for perpetual licenses for individual products. While the end of sale went well, what makes our Q4 results particularly good is that they were not driven by a dramatic surge in [indiscernible] opportunity buy-in of perpetual licenses. In fact, our analysis suggests that only a small portion, around 10% of our Q4 unit volume, is related to end-of-sale activity. More importantly, strong subscription growth, both new model and maintenance subscriptions, and a record number of large transactions drove these results. 
Our total unit volume for the fourth quarter was flat compared to the fourth quarter of last year, which was a major accomplishment. Recall that in Q4 last year, we had a significant uptick in demand related to the end of our upgrade program. Said another way, we were able to cover last year's Q4 uptick in unit volume with our new model subscription offering. When you look at total unit volume for the year, we were pleased to see volume of approximately 650,000 [ph] licenses. The total of subscription additions for the quarter was better than expected at 190,000. As we've seen all year, the additions were led by new model subscriptions with strong growth in all 3 types: Desktop, enterprise and cloud subscriptions. 
Desktop subscriptions remain our fastest-growing new model subscription offering and grew nearly 300% year-over-year. More specifically, desktop subscription is thriving with our channel partners. In just the past fourth [ph] quarter, the channel volume of desktop subscription has increased by more than 400%. In Q4, approximately 65% of our desktop subscription volume came through our channel partner, which is up in less than 50% [ph] in Q4 last year. 
What's still also notable is that we achieved our highest quarter for new model subs for the year and highest ever in terms of organic new model sub adds in the same quarter that we hit the end of sale of perpetual licenses for individual products, a remarkable achievement. For the year, we added 50% more new model subs than maintenance subs, even as maintenance attached and renewal rates move to record highs. The growth in new model subscriptions [indiscernible] 74% [ph] constant currency growth in new model ARR. Total recurring revenue grew to 53% of revenue compared to 47% in the fourth quarter last year. 
We're also pleased to see the unit volumes to our [indiscernible] strong growth and we believe that our online business will continue to grow to increase meaningfully. When you add in the business we do directly with enterprise customers, our overall direct business grew to 21% of our revenue volume compared to just 17% and 16% for the past 2 years. We set a record for the number of large deals in the quarter. Overall, a 19% increase in total deal count. The majority of these large deals were flexible enterprise licenses or EBAs, which are helping to drive subscription growth. Specifically, existing enterprise customers that moved from one of the former license [indiscernible] to the newer [indiscernible] CBAs have resulted in subscriber growth 3x [ph] higher than before. That's pretty meaningful. Just as a reminder, for those of you keeping score at home, the new Token Flex CBAs that we signed up this quarter, over 20,000, won't start to show up in accounts until next quarter. 
Large enterprise deals signaled that we are becoming a more strategic and essential quarter to our largest customers. Our long-term vision and position as the thought leader in the industry is an essential part of their commitment to us. To summarize, Q4 provides a nice proof point that the business model transition is working for our customers, our partners and us. I couldn't be happier with the results. 
Now that we've covered the past quarter, let me turn to long-term value creation. Given the short-term impact that the model transition is having on our traditional financial metrics, the recent turmoil in the stock market, growing fears about a global macroeconomic slowdown and the noise created by investors focused on the short-term, I think it's worth stepping back and taking a few minutes to outline how we are creating long-term value for our shareholders. First, we are dramatically increasing the lifetime value of our customers with our new business model. While this creates short-term downward pressure on our traditional financing metrics, we have repeatedly called out how we create significant funding to returns over the next 3 to 5 years. 
Second, we are simplifying our entire go-to-market strategy to align with the concept of being an all-subscription company. This involves a significant increase in our direct customer sales and marketing efforts, both at the enterprise level and to e-commerce. Not only will this change the cost structure, but it will increase -- it will greatly increase our effectivity to serve our customers. 
And the third and most importantly, we are exporting products to deliver more compelling product to recurring customers and dramatically expand the size of our market opportunities. Our early investment in cloud-based design and engineering have given us a once [indiscernible] generation opportunity to reinvent both the construction and manufacturing software market. Mainstream mobile and cloud technologies have opened up the market with more than 100 million potential subscribers. 
Thirdly, we have made substantial investments to achieve our leadership position, and let me be as clear as possible. The technology platforms for the future are all designed in engineering software. Really, all software is the cloud. And the company that wins will have substantial and sustainable long-term advantage. 
To summarize, our framework to building long-term shareholder value is to increase the lifetime value of every customer, change our cost structure, the means by which we reach customers, and finally, build the best cloud-based products and services in the industry. 
So while generalities are important, let me specifically highlight recent activity in terms of these long-term objectives. Most importantly, our business model transition is underway and exceeding expectations. For the second half of this year, we will fully be in the subscription-only mode. Customer and partner reactions to our new business model have been very positive, which gives me great confidence about our approach to the transition. Next, we continue to gauge and making sure of our costs. In Q4, we [indiscernible] flat year-over-year. We recently did a sizable restructuring that balances the need for financial discipline and its ability to invest in critical initiatives that drive the long-term health of the company. In September, we discussed annual operating expense growth of 5% to 6%. The restructuring, combined with other cost-cutting measures, has allowed us to put a significant cap on spending for the next 2 [ph] years. And we're committed to keeping spending growth roughly flat to slightly down through FY '17 and FY '18. 
And finally, our cloud-based products are the undisputed leaders in their respective categories. While many people are focused on the business model shift, many of the leadership positions in the cloud leads to a long-term sustainable competitive advantage. Building a great company over the long term requires balance in the interest of shareholders, employees and customers. Done well, these are not mutually exclusive. [indiscernible] we talked about it's harder to do, and I'm very proud of the many awards we received that recognized our success in doing just that. A few in particular worth mentioning are we were selected fro Fortune's world 25 best multinational workplaces, Fortune's 100 best companies to work for, and we're in the top 5 of Fortune's most admired software companies. We also are getting countless awards for innovation and product leadership. Bringing it all together, we are updating our long-term cash flow market. As for the to FY '20, assuming that the number of outstanding shares remains constant, we will be able to produce about $6 of free cash flow per share. In the following years, free cash flow continues to dramatically increase, and we see a path to free cash flow that [indiscernible] $2.5 billion or more than $11 per share of free cash flow by FY '20. As you are aware, our cash flow generation this year and next will be impacted by the transition from perpetual to term-based licenses. The silver lining is that we now have an opportunity to switch to a new operating structure to support our business needs. This change will result in an increase in our U.S.-based cash by lowering our long-term tax rate. This will greatly help with a long-term structural and balance of our ongoing revenues and cash flows as we move through the business model transition. We will give you more details during this year as our plans materialize. 
As we change to fiscal 2017, we couldn't be more excited about entering this next phase of our business. This year, we'll be the most unique in the company's history as we complete the transition from perpetual licenses to cloud-based subscriptions at the end of Q2. That will be interesting and unique quarterly pattern. None of the traditional seasonality patterns or sales metrics will be applicable. [indiscernible] year-over-year growth rates of traditional financial metrics be helpful in understanding how we're performing through the transition. 
Q1 will be our first quarter with only subscription offerings for individual products. We have a number of sales promotions in place to accelerate our customers' move to desktop subscription. As you think about Q1, the best results for us would be to be higher on subscriptions and lower on revenue. Now this may seem counterintuitive, but, in fact, would result from an accelerated transition to desktop subs. The end of Q2 will be the next major milestone of our business model transition as we start selling perpetual licenses for Suites. We expect the dynamics will most closely resemble what we saw in Q4 with the end of sale for individual products. Q3 will be our first quarter of subscription-only sales across the board and will likely experience potential slowdown. Our Q4 should begin to show more normal sales trends in our new subscription-only model. In our view, the better metrics will track our progress over the next few quarters will be subscription additions and the ARR growth. The entire company has been realigned and is hyperfocused on subscription additions and growth in recurring revenue. We have put in place both the positive and incentives, which is new sales, comp and bonus plans to align with our goal of growing our subscription base by a 20% CAGR over the next 4 years, which will drive a 24% CAGR in the ARR. 
Many of you have asked about impact of the macroeconomic environment on our business. We've said in past several quarters that the global conditions have been unaided. Most of the emerging markets have been a mess, but most of the mature markets have been decent. As we evaluated our strong Q4 results, we didn't see any further degradation in the demand environment. 
However, there is no denying there is clear divergence and sentiment with regards to global macroeconomic conditions. Coupled with the uniqueness of this year, our forecasting process has never been more challenging. As such, we believe it's prudent to taking appropriately conservative approach to our outlook for the year, while remaining confident in our ability to achieve our long-term target. For the year, we're projecting to add approximately 500,000 subscriptions, with new model subscriptions contributing to vast majority of growth. As expected, this will be the year, where the transition cost is the biggest revenue impact as we move more fully into this subscription. 
On the earnings call last quarter, I talked about 1% to 2% [ph] same growth for FY '17. Given that our [indiscernible] annual spend increase starts in about 4% just in healthcare cost, et cetera, some cost actions were already factored into our guidance. And repeatedly about reducing our spend growth while staying the course for the investments required to make both the business model and platform transition. Examples of these investment in building out a low-cost, high-touch inside sales team or in building out our cloud platform and products. We are constantly impacted by cutting spending too much or not reducing it enough could have on the rate and open the success of the transition. We believe our current course of management spend grew flat to moderately down for FY '17 [indiscernible] And as I previously mentioned, we will maintain flat growth throughout FY '18 as well. 
We are [indiscernible] saving the entire framework we laid out at the Investor Day last September, but there are a couple of data points that should be helping you with longer-term modeling. As I said earlier with the updates to the model overall, we see FCF per share of roughly $6 in FY '20, given our current view of topline growth and our spend trajectory. Our revenue production for FY '17 is slightly lower than the framework we provided in September for a few reasons. Continued FX headwinds are pushing revenue down. We are assuming a higher mix of new model sub-based on our recent performance. And as I mentioned earlier, we're taking a more conservative stance, given all the moving parts this year. 
Similar to our view in Q1, hitting the low end of our revenue range, while exceeding our subscription guidance, is a desirable outcome for the year. If we experienced greater-than-expected demand for the last perpetual licenses for Suites, it will likely drive revenue to the high end of guidance or beyond. 
To wrap things up, we're really excited to be 1 step further along in the transition. Our long-term strategy will provide our customers with greater flexibility, more compelling products and a better user experience. In doing so, we're driving higher lifetime customer value, simplify our go-to-market and significantly increasing the size of the available market. Simultaneously, we are reducing our cost structure to celebrate our transition and increase our profitability as well as evolving our operating and tax structure to better meet our future business needs. In short, we are creating a more predictable, recurring and profitable business for Autodesk for Autodesk in the years to come. Finally, I'd like to thank all of our employees and our workers who work so hard to make last year a success. 
Operator, we'd now like to open up the call to questions.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Phil Winslow from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Phil Winslow from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I really appreciate that update on the outlook, it certainly is impressive on the cash flow metrics. Clearly, above your old guidance and above you and where we were. When you look at those cash flow's long-term target you gave up there, I know you're not
componenttext: I really appreciate that update on the outlook, it certainly is impressive on the cash flow metrics. Clearly, above your old guidance and above you and where we were. When you look at those cash flow's long-term target you gave up there, I know you're not updating the whole framework. But it certainly implies, it seems, like margins are solidly ahead of what you talked about the Analyst Day. And obviously, you talked about fiscal '17 and fiscal '18 on the cost side. I wonder if you get us just sort of how you're thinking about the framework margin kind of in that long-term guidance? And then from a top line perspective, sort of how you're building up there, obviously not giving the full details that you guys talked about? And then just one quick follow-up to that.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So let me just quickly touch on, and then Scott can jump in. Most of the update in guidance was not a change of the overall demand. So let's just put that out there, kind of us assuming the same level as demand. We were pleased in Q4 to see a greater
componenttext: Yes. So let me just quickly touch on, and then Scott can jump in. Most of the update in guidance was not a change of the overall demand. So let's just put that out there, kind of us assuming the same level as demand. We were pleased in Q4 to see a greater demand, no difference in demand from when we talked about the model. A lot of the upside is driven by greater cost control, so a lot has to do with some of the stuff we outlined for FY '17 and '18. And just as you roll out through the subsequent years, it's just starting from a lower cost base has a tremendous advantage. And in a lot of ways, that's what we were responding to. Many of our investors have said, I understand the transition. I love to where you're getting on the other side. But [indiscernible] control cost's a little bit better through this transition. I think in response to that, that's what we got and that's where we see a lot of it. The other slide shift I'd say is we're more optimistic about the move to the new model. We've seen more positive signs of acceptance by both customers and partners. And remember, a little bit of our reluctance to move more quickly is making sure we had acceptance of both groups and the ability for them to successfully navigate the transition as well as us.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Phil, this is Scott. The only other thing I would add is the framework we laid out is not intended to be something we update every quarter. But as you roll through the changes that we've talked about and spend the growth off through time, and then of
componenttext: And Phil, this is Scott. The only other thing I would add is the framework we laid out is not intended to be something we update every quarter. But as you roll through the changes that we've talked about and spend the growth off through time, and then of course, it doesn't step function back up after fiscal '18. It takes a while for that, for the spend engine to accelerate again. But we do see margins expanding. I think what we showed in the 29th was in that mid- to high 20% range in fiscal '20. And it's probably a good 4 to 5 points higher than that, given what we just talk about in spend.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, well, I was at $8 to $9 in free cash flow,  so I'm a big fan of your 11 [ph] So 1 just last follow-up on the quarter itself. You guys talked about the quarter strength was not driven by sort of the end of sale of licenses for some of the products.
componenttext: Great, well, I was at $8 to $9 in free cash flow,  so I'm a big fan of your 11 [ph] So 1 just last follow-up on the quarter itself. You guys talked about the quarter strength was not driven by sort of the end of sale of licenses for some of the products. Carl and Scott, I wonder if you can talk through just the verticals and geos, sort of what areas were sending out as particular areas of strength? And how are you thinking about that in terms of your guidance?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, so a couple of things about this. Let's start with the geos because it's really black and white. Every emerging economy, developing country, whatever you want to call it practically, thinks. The exception for us was China. So despite the news
componenttext: Yes, I mean, so a couple of things about this. Let's start with the geos because it's really black and white. Every emerging economy, developing country, whatever you want to call it practically, thinks. The exception for us was China. So despite the news that you may have read, China continues to perform well. But there are places, where our business in emerging markets is just totally tanked. So when you look at a number of these places, the Middle East, Russia, largely driven by oil, Brazil is bad. So you look there, when you compare geographically, our EMEA results look not as strong as the others. Two factors there. One is EMEA had a fabulous fourth quarter last year; and the second part is really the MEA part. The E part of EMEA did great, but the MEA part just struggled and it really is due to oil and commodities at other stuff. So the geographic part is pretty simple. Don't see a big change, I think relative to what we hear others talking about or reading in newspapers, if anyone still reads newspapers, China is better than you would expect from taking your readings. The only weak point of the developed world that has no doubt there is Japan. So Japan has been weak for a while, currency is an issue. But generally, we saw kind of flat demand. Of course, the market's both construction and manufacturing on Media and Entertainment were all good and there's a lot of difference to cross or I would point to. We'll call out any trends that we're seeing in and projecting into the future.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I agree with that. And by the way, with the commentary that we just gave on emerging market is really no different than what we've seen out here. We've seen China actually in a bit of a bright spot for us in the emerging markets. And everything else,
componenttext: Yes, I agree with that. And by the way, with the commentary that we just gave on emerging market is really no different than what we've seen out here. We've seen China actually in a bit of a bright spot for us in the emerging markets. And everything else, and in particular, Russia and Brazil, have really struggled year-on-year. The only other thing that stands out when you look through it was kind of strength across the board in Q4. And in particular, the number of large transactions that we did, the deal is greater than $1 million. It's heavily driven by our EBAs, our big enterprise agreements. We had a very strong quarter there and, in fact, more than a handful of 8-figure deals there. Now these are all ratable, so you don't see them all dropping in to the revenue stream in Q4, but a handful of 8-figure deals in the largest manufacturing [indiscernible] we've ever done, we just got it done in Q4. So I'd say strength at the high end as well.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Saket Kalia from Barclays.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Saket Kalia from Barclays.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Carl, you talked last quarter about selling anywhere from 500,000 to 800,000 unit in a given year. And I think you said it was about 650,000 this year, correct me if I'm wrong. You've given us the subscription component of that with the sub's guidance for
componenttext: Carl, you talked last quarter about selling anywhere from 500,000 to 800,000 unit in a given year. And I think you said it was about 650,000 this year, correct me if I'm wrong. You've given us the subscription component of that with the sub's guidance for fiscal '17. But just normalizing for all the noise in '17, how do you think about unit volume for fiscal '17?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think unit volume will be up. Not a huge amount, but up. One of the tricks that we kind of referencing and forecasting is that in particular, I think there was a couple of quarters, though it's hard to know which way people will go, Q1 and Q2 in particu
componenttext: I think unit volume will be up. Not a huge amount, but up. One of the tricks that we kind of referencing and forecasting is that in particular, I think there was a couple of quarters, though it's hard to know which way people will go, Q1 and Q2 in particular, but even extending into Q3. So we're doing our best job on triangulating from what we're hearing from our partners, what we're hearing from our salespeople, top-down models, extrapolation in trends. But to be honest, it's a little bit hard and that's why we have a slightly broader range in terms of guidance and why we gave the slightly paradoxical guidance that I wouldn't mind seeing revenue down. I think I've now done something like 40 [ph] of these earnings calls at the end of the quarter. And I don't think I've ever alluded for revenue to be down, but this maybe -- this is certainly a first. And so it's just different than it's ever been. I can't highlight enough that the next 4 quarters are just going to be a little bit odd. And that's why we pointed to you and I think you are on the right point, which is look at volume. We think volume will be up. Look at ARR, there will be a number of metrics will underlying -- it's really the foundation of the business doing well and for underlying demand. And then a little bit, which I think is the math that follows the [indiscernible] and just as the math is ugly in the next 1.5 years, the math is beautiful in the subsequent years. And so we'll take that as we handle 1 other addition. Let me just add what our bias is and I think strongly supportive by many of our investors is to do anything we can to transition our customers to the new model as fast as possible. So there are number of things like this stuff we're doing, which again, we think could adversely affect some of our guidance on revenue. But we think we'll also help on exceeding our subscriptions. So many of you have noticed things like promotions in Q1, I think you'll see promotions in Q1 around our new models businesses. I think just the same thing in Q3. That would not be out of the question for us to do stuff like that. So a number of things, but our bias is we'd already do stuff in the end of sale date by 6 months and now we're using all the knobs and leverage we have to continue to put pressure on the system to move to the new model as quickly as possible.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: That makes sense. And then for my follow-up, I'm not sure for color for Scott, but one of the difficult things that I find modeling externally is that ARPS number, particularly around new mode ARR. And so I'm not sure if this is something you've looked ba
componenttext: That makes sense. And then for my follow-up, I'm not sure for color for Scott, but one of the difficult things that I find modeling externally is that ARPS number, particularly around new mode ARR. And so I'm not sure if this is something you've looked back, but on a steady state basis in Q3, Q4 and beyond, based on the historical mix that you've seen, the historical volume and subscription pricing, what's the fair range to think about new model ARPS and sort of steady-state, if that makes sense?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I understand that the model drives, you don't want to focus on that metric, [indiscernible] this is the key, as what Carl said earlier. We geared the entire machine from sales comp through the variable comp bonus plans that every employee has. You lo
componenttext: Yes, I understand that the model drives, you don't want to focus on that metric, [indiscernible] this is the key, as what Carl said earlier. We geared the entire machine from sales comp through the variable comp bonus plans that every employee has. You look at our promos, u look at the way we will point our channel partners next week at our sales kickoff event. It's geared everything towards driving subs. Because the more we drive subs, and in particular, the more we drive the new model subs, ultimately, that's what builds the strength of the modeling and gets us to that vision of fiscal '20 that we've laid out. So ARPS to us is more of a drive number. We're focused on driving subs and driving ARR. And when you divide those 3, you get ARPS. I think, if you wanted to think about a little bit more mechanically, I'll give you 2 pointers. One is the fastest-growing piece of our desktop business, which is what's driving the new model subs as much as anything that's below end, is that the AutoCAD LT, the stock sub. That's not actually going to put downward pressure that ARPS. The second is the way we calculate ARR in a quarterly basis is we total up our recurring revenue for the quarter, multiply that by 4 and you get it annualized, and that's our ARR. And so the linearity in a given quarter will drive the ARR calculation. In other words, the model sales coming in late in the quarter, there's fewer revenue than actually accretive to the reported revenue for the quarter. And so you don't get to see the full effect of it until the following quarter. So there's a little bit of seasonality and linearity effect on ARR at any given quarter, but I think it also throw off your ARPS calculation.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, just in general, the one thing I would say about ARPS is I could see it's going to be slightly higher this year is more of a [indiscernible] than our full-fledged offerings hit. But as Scott pointed out, our lower cost products like the LT was put
componenttext: I mean, just in general, the one thing I would say about ARPS is I could see it's going to be slightly higher this year is more of a [indiscernible] than our full-fledged offerings hit. But as Scott pointed out, our lower cost products like the LT was putting pressure on the downward as well as many of the cloud subscriptions. So as we've talked about, many of those cloud subscriptions are from larger groups working to get as opposed to individual design and engineering products. So things like BIM 360 and PLM 360 with hundreds of thousands of users. And so the average cost per subscriber will be substantially lower than a designed product.  So it really is all cut up in that first [ph] quarter of average. It's driven by mix..

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, the comment that you made that in the desktop, it's the lower and that's really kind of driving the subscriptions at the moment, do you think that's just a matter of who's interested in adopting first and we'll see that mix change over time? Or is
componenttext: Scott, the comment that you made that in the desktop, it's the lower and that's really kind of driving the subscriptions at the moment, do you think that's just a matter of who's interested in adopting first and we'll see that mix change over time? Or is there something about the subscription format that's going to drive users more towards a lower-end product versus some of the higher-end products?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's just that we introduced the first. From a volume standpoint, though, that's absolutely right. It's nothing inherently advantageous of buying a subscription on LT versus buying a subscription on AutoCAD or PRDS or any other products. It is the highest
componenttext: It's just that we introduced the first. From a volume standpoint, though, that's absolutely right. It's nothing inherently advantageous of buying a subscription on LT versus buying a subscription on AutoCAD or PRDS or any other products. It is the highest volume product, and given that t it is our highest volume product in perpetual sales, it will be our highest volume product on recurring scales s well.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: But we really focus on the first [indiscernible] One of our concerns going into this transition was the customers who are more paying for the flagship products will be very comfortable with the new models. But then some of the LT uses were more casual and
componenttext: But we really focus on the first [indiscernible] One of our concerns going into this transition was the customers who are more paying for the flagship products will be very comfortable with the new models. But then some of the LT uses were more casual and might not want to enter into longer-term commitments, so we focus very heavily, given that it was our highest volume product on making it go there. So I think what we're seeing a little bit is we're measuring the effect of our influence on this. Now a better time to make a measurement will be as we hit Q3 and we get to the -- when we get to the end of sale, the perpetual licenses for Suites as well as introduce our new offerings that are really the desktop replacements for Suites.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And as a follow-up, you mentioned a couple of times the good results in terms of the large deals. Was there anything in particular that you saw stood up to drive some of those deals in terms of the timing, whether it just be year-end budget flash
componenttext: Got it. And as a follow-up, you mentioned a couple of times the good results in terms of the large deals. Was there anything in particular that you saw stood up to drive some of those deals in terms of the timing, whether it just be year-end budget flash for particular types of problems that those customers are trying to solve were doing these larger deals?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think there were a couple of things that have happened, some short term, some long term. One is that there is always more of the seasonality to our large enterprise deals. Some of it is driven by the end of year. And remember, even though one of the
componenttext: No, I think there were a couple of things that have happened, some short term, some long term. One is that there is always more of the seasonality to our large enterprise deals. Some of it is driven by the end of year. And remember, even though one of the works of this company is our calendar in fiscal numbering, it does give us a second close, so we not only have the customer end of year, but our salespeople haven't ended the year, too. And so there's always been a stronger influence in Q4 because of that. So the second thing is if you go back a handful of years, we had almost no enterprise licenses. That was a nonexistent part of our business and I think we get a number of things over the midterm the change that. One is we build out the Salesforce that did it. We changed the nature of some of our products and better accommodated. We had licensing models that are more what they wanted to do. And I think, our drive, really, to take a leadership position in the industry, whether that's what we're doing a Media and Entertainment or BIM 360 or doing on the cloud and manufacturing has led companies to view Autodesk as a more strategic partner. Other than that, how many years we have to go back before I would find that, a million-dollar deal in the quarter with a big deal? And now it's fairly routine. So we've invested heavily. As we detailed at Analyst Day this year and last year, we think there's a lot more there. We think the offerings enabled us to grow much more quickly. And what we love about it is it does have some trickle-down effect in that all of these companies greatly affect the supply chain. So we're really excited about the enterprise that is, and we're going to continue to keep investing in it. As a matter of fact, the biggest investment chain during the 2008, 2009 downturn when we recognized like our statistical run rate business was falling off and one of the places we could really invest was in the enterprise. And it was really out of ahead of that soul searching in the darkness that we really landed on this. And it's just been a continual success.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Heather Bellini from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask a little bit about your maintenance ARR, which declined in the quarter. And I guess, after you cancel Suites licenses at the end of the second quarter, should we expect the declines in the maintenance ARR to accelerate? I'm just think
componenttext: I just wanted to ask a little bit about your maintenance ARR, which declined in the quarter. And I guess, after you cancel Suites licenses at the end of the second quarter, should we expect the declines in the maintenance ARR to accelerate? I'm just think about it, it's a high-margin the maintenance streams. So what's baked into your assumptions on how this should decline for fiscal '17 given your earnings guidance? And then I just have a follow-up.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me just say one word -- this is Scott. Yes, you absolutely should count our maintenance ARR going down after the end of Q2. I wouldn't say -- I don't know if accelerate is the right word, but this is, again, l1 of the trends we've talked about ba
componenttext: Yes, let me just say one word -- this is Scott. Yes, you absolutely should count our maintenance ARR going down after the end of Q2. I wouldn't say -- I don't know if accelerate is the right word, but this is, again, l1 of the trends we've talked about back at Investor Day that, as we said in our last perpetual license, that will be the apex on maintenance subscriptions, which will come down at a rate consistent with our churn rate, and of course, maintenance ARR will trail down as well. There's a lot of maintenance sitting in deferred revenue, right? So it's not going to come off quickly out of reported revenues, but it will trickle-down. It will become, in the second half of the year, both maintenance ARR and maintenance subscriptions growth to be a headwind to our total ARR and total subtractions growth.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the follow-up question and I guess, there's actually 2 quick ones. Your new model ARR increased by about $35 million in the quarter. How do we think about that ramping throughout fiscal '17? Is there a target we should be thinking of? Or do
componenttext: Okay. And then the follow-up question and I guess, there's actually 2 quick ones. Your new model ARR increased by about $35 million in the quarter. How do we think about that ramping throughout fiscal '17? Is there a target we should be thinking of? Or do you guys have a goal in mind? If you can share so we can benchmark how you do versus expectations? And then the other question were getting at a lot about -- you gave us some of the pieces, but how are you thinking about your cash flow for fiscal '17?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. First, Heather, we're not providing ARR guidance for the year, certainly not at that granularity. I think, again, that we saw [indiscernible] and I said that, I mean, every part of the company to focus on driving subs. And so the easy place to descri
componenttext: Yes. First, Heather, we're not providing ARR guidance for the year, certainly not at that granularity. I think, again, that we saw [indiscernible] and I said that, I mean, every part of the company to focus on driving subs. And so the easy place to describe right now through this year will be to track how we grow both total and subscriptions, but then more importantly, the new model subscriptions, that's what's going to grow the company longer term. On cash flow, I said a couple of things. Cash flow for Q4 was artificially low. We did have -- we had very interesting linearity in a quarter, where the third [ph] month of the quarter, so January for us, so more than half of our total sales get done. And since we built in that 30, [ph] we had a lot of -- in a normal linearity, a normal 30, 40 or the normal that we have experienced in the past few years, we would've seen about [ph] $95 million more cash flow from ops fall into Q4. But given the linearity in the quarter, given those sales got found late, that's all sitting in receivables. By the way, our receivables is 100% current, so there's not -- there's no risk on that. But it is saying in receivables and will now be collected in Q1. So what it means is there's a headwind on the cash flow from ops just reported for Q4. That will just ripple over into Q1. It you remember, all we said for cash flow, our free cash flow back at Investor Day, we side we thought it would be breakeven to slightly negative for fiscal '17, and that now goes up by about $100 million year-over-year. So think of it being certainly positive, somewhere around that $50 million to $100 million range.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line from Jay Vleeschhouwer from Griffin Securities.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line from Jay Vleeschhouwer from Griffin Securities.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Carl, in the second half of this year, after you terminate perpetual for Suites, you'll be introducing your so-called Collections. You've stated before that this is one of the opportunities you have to reduce the complexity in your business. Could you tal
componenttext: Carl, in the second half of this year, after you terminate perpetual for Suites, you'll be introducing your so-called Collections. You've stated before that this is one of the opportunities you have to reduce the complexity in your business. Could you talk about how you've anticipated, perhaps, the cost savings and the selling process from introducing these new collections and improving or aiding the eoverall scalability process of introducing that?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the way -- so let me just break this part into 2 halves, Jay. I don't think our, any of our financial guidance is just predicated on what we're going to do with collections, but we can think about it a lot. We would really like to simplify the offering
componenttext: So the way -- so let me just break this part into 2 halves, Jay. I don't think our, any of our financial guidance is just predicated on what we're going to do with collections, but we can think about it a lot. We would really like to simplify the offering for the whole number of operational reasons.  So it's incredibly important that we do that. The second and probably more important thing that we're trying to accomplish with collections is to give an incentive for the existing customers, who are on maintenance for Suites, a more attractive thing to move over to. So as we said, we want to try to use the carrot as much is possible to convince our customers, our best customers, who are on maintenance a description to move over. And that's what we really trying to do. At the same time, it's a great way to some of our product portfolio. So we're going to use it for both those things. I think the important -- and we'll kind of get a better read on it as we go through the year, but a lot of the financial modeling we've been talking about so far this afternoon is really predicated on overall volume. And we're not assuming any kind of outsized performance from collections.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. At the analyst meeting, you mentioned that about 1/10 of your Named Accounts have already adopted EBAs, and I was wondering if you now have an updated adoption rate in light of the strength you highlighted for large deals in Q4? And looking out
componenttext: All right. At the analyst meeting, you mentioned that about 1/10 of your Named Accounts have already adopted EBAs, and I was wondering if you now have an updated adoption rate in light of the strength you highlighted for large deals in Q4? And looking out, how would you talk about the pipeline or assumptions of close in the EBA pipeline for fiscal '17? Our understanding is that you've got a number of interesting names in terms of the industrial automotive accounts for example and perhaps, you could talk about that.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Yes, I mean, we do. We have a-determia lot of really large manufacturers and large construction companies. I mean, there's certainly other companies in their Media and Entertainment companies. So it there. It's focused on large manufacturing and larg
componenttext: Yes. Yes, I mean, we do. We have a-determia lot of really large manufacturers and large construction companies. I mean, there's certainly other companies in their Media and Entertainment companies. So it there. It's focused on large manufacturing and large construction companies. I said, I don't think we've hit 20% yet, so we're somewhere in that 10% to 20%. I don't know the precise number of this point, what I meant there's still a lot of each growth. And what's particularly good about this is the  growth the business as much number of accounts. It's a growth within those accounts that is what is so substantial. So it's not like we signed an EBA [indiscernible] remember there's a consumption-based aspect of this as well. And when we tried details why we think it's a win-win. And so the existing EBAs continue to grow, and more than 80% [ph] of our large customers are still not on these flexible licenses. The last part, just to tie both your questions together, Jay, is essentially Collections is a form of flexible licensing for smaller customers that can be sold through the channel. So what we really want to do is use the patterns, just see the model that works so well for the enterprise and bring it to small and medium businesses and allow our partners that sell sound more flexible consumption-based licenses as well.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016

componenttext: It's actually Stan Zlotsky sitting in for Keith. Wanted to come back to the restructuring that you guys announced, 10% headcount being taken out. Where are the -- does the costs that are being taken out, where are they being reinvested as we had jhead fiscal '17?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I mean there's only a small amount of reinvestment. But what we want to think about is  are probably 3 areas, where we are doing reinvestment. One area is moving to more inside sales, which I think is really important. The second is we continue to buil
componenttext: So I mean there's only a small amount of reinvestment. But what we want to think about is  are probably 3 areas, where we are doing reinvestment. One area is moving to more inside sales, which I think is really important. The second is we continue to build out our back office. So remember, these flexible license offerings we  talked about, we are so proud about. We actually need to build the infrastructure to support that. Consumption-based models need it, so we're still investing in doing that. And then the third thing that we're doing is -- and I know it's gotten a lot less focus, I feel like I heard on head and talked about this and it still doesn't matter, but the really big thing we're doing is investing in the cloud and mobile and we're trying to change the dynamics of the market. And we are continuing to invest in that, and so some of it is tied to cloud infrastructure and things like that. As you step down a level, you would see things like continued investment in our enterprise salesforce. There are things that are working, but some of that, first of all in the categories of the regular engineering you do within a business. Yes, Clearly, we have less people selling an industrial industry and more people on major accounts. So hopefully, Stan, those gives you kind of the areas.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's very helpful. And maybe one more for Scott, what layers of conservatism -- or maybe, how did you approach your thinking around the midpoint of 500,000 guidance for subs for fiscal '17? And that's it for me.
componenttext: Yes, that's very helpful. And maybe one more for Scott, what layers of conservatism -- or maybe, how did you approach your thinking around the midpoint of 500,000 guidance for subs for fiscal '17? And that's it for me.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Stan, we really built this bottoms up, so we looked at a handful of things. One is we already talked about, which is we hit the end of sale of perpetual licenses for Suites midyear. We expect some buying behavior much like we saw at the very end of Q
componenttext: Yes, Stan, we really built this bottoms up, so we looked at a handful of things. One is we already talked about, which is we hit the end of sale of perpetual licenses for Suites midyear. We expect some buying behavior much like we saw at the very end of Q4 when we hit end of sales on individual products. So I think that will be -- that will put some upward pressure on maintenance subs in the first half of the year. But in the second half of the year, there's no new maintenance sub. And while we have a high renewal rate on maintenance, it's not 100%. So maintenance turns around accounts for the full year, it becomes a headwind for us for subscriber adds. The remainder of looking at what we think -- what we've seen this year, what we think will happen in terms of unit volumes. And knowing  that for the second half of the year, those unit volumes will all be in some form or fashion, is instructions account. And so it's putting those 2 together and really putting it bottoms up with the assumption on renewal rates that leads us to that midpoint.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. If you  just look at the numbers, those are the ones that we can most have the greatest confidence in. As opposed to the question about conservatism, we probably are too conservative on the side of some of the cloud subscriptions. I think there's a l
componenttext: Yes. If you  just look at the numbers, those are the ones that we can most have the greatest confidence in. As opposed to the question about conservatism, we probably are too conservative on the side of some of the cloud subscriptions. I think there's a lot more to be done there, and I think this is going to look much more like the adoption of any new technology. There will be a tipping point. I can't tell you exactly where it is. We're happy with the growth rates we see today, but there will be a tipping point is as we've seen with these options of almost every other technology we've ever introduced.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016

componenttext: Maybe a question first for Scott. In terms of your spend target for next year being kind of flat to down 1%, any conservative baked into that particular number? I know -- I get from the topline of the subscriber base perspective, it's particularly tough to gauge what might happen. But from spending, you guys generally control most of that, so...

componenttext: Yes, I wouldn't say there is aggressiveness or conservatism built into that number. And that's not fully in our control. [indiscernible] the only variable there is a variable comp goes away out because we have a blowout year. Beyond that, and by the way, we gauge that on subscriber growth. So I think that will actually be a good thing if it went up. The spend number is we've got the pretty firm handle on the.

componenttext: Got you. And then the follow-up, Carl, in terms of your kind of new subs, what are you guys seeing on renewal rates? Maybe not specific renewal rates, but relative to internal targets, is that coming in better than expected? And how should we take about that going forward?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean so far, so good. All of that is really kind. Yes, I really.
componenttext: Yes, I mean so far, so good. All of that is really kind. Yes, I really.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think when you look at both the patents are or the maintenance are, as we look at attach rate and renewal and, of course, in the new model subs, we look at renewal And we've seen upward pressure across the board of both attach rates and renewal rates. S
componenttext: I think when you look at both the patents are or the maintenance are, as we look at attach rate and renewal and, of course, in the new model subs, we look at renewal And we've seen upward pressure across the board of both attach rates and renewal rates. So there's -- I'd say that's one [indiscernible] as Carl talked about, we look at next year or fiscal '17 with a lot of excitement and a lot of that space going what we've seen now in terms of acceptance of the new models and what we're also seeing on kind of the general bias up towards.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think it will continue. I mean, if you want to think about this, with the end of sales of perpetual licenses for individual products last quarter and the ones for Suites next quarter, customers have more incentive than ever to stay on the program th
componenttext: And I think it will continue. I mean, if you want to think about this, with the end of sales of perpetual licenses for individual products last quarter and the ones for Suites next quarter, customers have more incentive than ever to stay on the program that they're on. So in the past, somebody could get off and then get back on relatively painlessly. That is no longer a possibility by the second half of this year. So I think it will continue to lead pressure on an upward bias.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Perfect. And then at the Analyst Day, you've outlay -- gave an outline chart showing what you thought that revenue might be going up to FY '22, what expenses might be, margins might be. You've already commented that you're tweaking it a little bit and scr
componenttext: Perfect. And then at the Analyst Day, you've outlay -- gave an outline chart showing what you thought that revenue might be going up to FY '22, what expenses might be, margins might be. You've already commented that you're tweaking it a little bit and screwing down the expense growth a little more than that. And in the near term, maybe the revenue is in what you thought. But if we look at those out years of FY '21 and '22, is your revenue expectation for that still similar to what it was back at Analyst Day?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So let me start at the end and then I'll work backwards. So the answer is yes. Our revenue outlook in the out years is still exactly what we outlined. Back to the beginning of your question, I would say relative to September, our expenses are much lo
componenttext: Yes. So let me start at the end and then I'll work backwards. So the answer is yes. Our revenue outlook in the out years is still exactly what we outlined. Back to the beginning of your question, I would say relative to September, our expenses are much lower, considerably lower, just to put -- from 5% to 6% that we said was kind of the feeling, now we're talking about flat for the next 2 years and then moderating from there. So it's substantial when you run to model, it has a dramatic effect, particularly having down to flat in the first few years of this transition. The revenue, which we think slightly, but the revenue is not about unit demand, as we said. It's really whether people buy the new model or the old model. And also through this year, we'll still have some variability, and so inability to predict exactly what happens. The good news is we moved to the end of that year, there's only 1 thing that people can buy new from us. And so while in many ways, this is painful to go through the transition, we do hit a point, probably in the middle of next year, where 80% or 90% of the revenue in a quarter comes off the balance sheet. So if I go back to when I first started, you started every quarter in 0, you're now going in a place where you start every quarter with 80% or 90% of the tank full. And that -- we use the word business model transition and maybe some think it's wild, but absolutely, that's really what it means. And so our ability to predict that gets us very good at that point, and your ability to model it gets a very good at that point as you watch as at the ARR.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Carl touched on this earlier, it's a somewhat paradoxical year. So if you -- to the extent that customers continue to move more quickly to a new model, that's going to put downward pressure on the current year's recorded revenues. However, when you look o
componenttext: Carl touched on this earlier, it's a somewhat paradoxical year. So if you -- to the extent that customers continue to move more quickly to a new model, that's going to put downward pressure on the current year's recorded revenues. However, when you look out in time, especially when you get into fiscal '19 and fiscal '20, we talked about this, the overall majority of our revenues are going to be driven by the model subs. So while -- [indiscernible] move to new model will result in lower end on reported revenues for this year, it actually is good news for building up that base and getting to the numbers we laid out in the out years.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Gregg Moskowitz from Cowen & Company.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Gregg Moskowitz from Cowen & Company.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Carl, was wondering if you can give us a bit more insight into recent customer behavior in conjunction with the termination of perpetual standalone for customers that opted not to buy 1 last license prior to the end of January to allow them to buy a subsc
componenttext: Carl, was wondering if you can give us a bit more insight into recent customer behavior in conjunction with the termination of perpetual standalone for customers that opted not to buy 1 last license prior to the end of January to allow them to buy a subscription instead before the end of the months. Did they wait 1, 2, 3 weeks after the quarter and move forward? Or are they yet to make a decision? Just wondering any more color you can provide effective at the customer just from what you've seen and heard so far.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: What it looks like is the most of the customers are moving to desktop subscription. That's the general one. There is still in of choices out there and [indiscernible] people that we can totally account for. But we don't really know, and we don't get a muc
componenttext: What it looks like is the most of the customers are moving to desktop subscription. That's the general one. There is still in of choices out there and [indiscernible] people that we can totally account for. But we don't really know, and we don't get a much better feel in Q3 as this becomes the only way to buy. But from all the anecdotal information, talking to our partners, the people are tending to do is buy desktop subscriptions. Like we said, we got about 10% of the volume was, people who were taking advantage of the last moment opportunity to buy. I think we'll see that again in Q2. Maybe slightly stronger in the Suites, but I'm not convinced of that yet. But many people are finding desktop subscription the only attractive alternative. And maybe when we start talking about as a couple of years ago, we were [indiscernible] something about that. We are no longer the top poll in the 10th. The entire software industry is moving to these kinds of licensing models and customers are just getting much more comfortable. And they understand what the benefit of them is buying this way. So I think there will be some noise for a while, but by the second half of the year, we're well into the single model, and by next year, it's kind of all done.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Greg, I think 1 of the best indicators is when you look at that Q4 results, not only do we see, as Carl said, a small buyers on the perpetual side, we have the biggest quarter we've ever had or organic new subscription had. So we actually saw both at
componenttext: And Greg, I think 1 of the best indicators is when you look at that Q4 results, not only do we see, as Carl said, a small buyers on the perpetual side, we have the biggest quarter we've ever had or organic new subscription had. So we actually saw both at the same time. It wasn't buy 1 or buy the other. We have the biggest quarter ever for new model subscription add and we had the end of sales, which all combine the activity of perpetual licenses. So I think it's something to say. I'm going to be this or I'm going to be that. What we're seeing is both are happening in 2 different customer set.

If we just talk about the linearity of Q4, which is a strong quarter from any dimension, but because of the linearity, a lot of the sales that came in Q4, come into that third month and depressed or recorded cash -- free cash flows for Q4 by about $95 million, which now have shifted from Q4 and into Q1. So I think, when linearity being such a large variable there, it's really hard to say this quarter definitively is going to be the bottom. But I think what's happening in fiscal '17 from a free cash flow standpoint and then from an accumulated cash standpoint, [indiscernible] is fiscal '18.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, good question.  I mean, I think it's partially what I just answered is that we start -- so for example, we start building a model, in which almost all of the revenue comes off the balance sheet. So just starting with that idea that quarter used to st
componenttext: Yes, good question.  I mean, I think it's partially what I just answered is that we start -- so for example, we start building a model, in which almost all of the revenue comes off the balance sheet. So just starting with that idea that quarter used to start and in and will now start at 80 or 90 or 95 is different. You will also be able to look at things like the churn and see the renewal rates and extrapolate from there. So to the extent that -- and we generally haven't gone out that far, but people really do understand the dynamic of this. And so we were just trying to put in perspective. I mean, to extent you want to discount FY '23, [ph] feel free to. It's a way in the future. I think the FY '20 is there. The problem we have, and really, the reason why we gave details around FY '23 is because FY '20 or FY '21 is still so much in the steep part of the curve. And so if we -- when we were doing that, we're only talking about FY '20, people were saying, is that the terminal? Was it the terminal cash flow? Is that the terminal EPS, is that the terminal operating margin? And it wasn't. And just to the extent now that traditional financial metrics are going to go down predictably as a result of how we account for this, it's just as certain that they come up on the other side. So I think I'm totally fine with people want to discount FY '23. We just wanted to make sure that people understand that that's what our model looks like. And if you back off it and look, we've been [indiscernible] some people who think we should be able to get a lot more, there is some people who get less. But then look at it any pretty reasonable way about 30,000 [ph] number of subscribers. Because remember, if anything, we have been attacked for ARPS. So there's not a lot of assumptions about ARPS going up, so it really is all about subscribers and then ARR's with we translates directly to revenue. So book whatever discounts you want on it, Brent.

componenttext: I wanted to ask a little bit about the long-term trajectory when it comes to thinking about new users, and I know that there is definite definitional issues they are. But if we suppose that of your 650,000 seat sales run rate, let's just say for the sake of argument, half of those are kind of new users for the half are people that are active, but weren't regularly paying and maybe buying a new license or something. If I -- unless they think about that the right way, if we can assume that, what happens to that new user addition number as you move through the transition? there that 300,000 go up to adding pirated users? It probably should go up -- you should be adding those old license users at subscriptions, but then those become renewals later in -- as so do we think about the unit sales as we move a lot in the transition?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We would hope to see those continually going up. We've been pretty modest in our consumption. But you're right, you have the old subscribers. And remember, the definitional issue is really a user could be in a different company, but they've user before an
componenttext: We would hope to see those continually going up. We've been pretty modest in our consumption. But you're right, you have the old subscribers. And remember, the definitional issue is really a user could be in a different company, but they've user before and let's just ignore that for a second. But the old subscribers would be there. Piracy, we think, will put a significant dent in casual privacy. And as we said to new offerings, other places, where we're getting new customers. So kind of this different way. We talked about sometimes the TAM expansion, we talked about it as new users. I referenced 100 [ph] million people in manufacturing and construction, who didn't have a meaningful for many of the tools we previously sold. We do now, whether that's BIM 360 or PLM 360, those are new users -- of those to users maybe inside of existing customers or they may be in new accounts. But we can give you an indication of many of these products are notably high in almost all cases, a majority of the customers that are doing it, our nontraditional customers. The other thing that I think is really important, and I know you guys do not want to pay too much to listen to your model, but we're running a business, not a spreadsheet. And in our world, the investments we've made in going to cloud-based engineering tools has led us to have a leadership position in that. We deeply believe that the future of all software is in the cloud and in mobile and it opens up big markets. I've always believed for people who invest in Autodesk, this is one of the fundamental tenets you should believe in. There are less difficult ways to get there, but we think the business model transition starts the curve we just talked about with Brent, but if that is going to continue into the out years, that's based on the fact that we expand in to new markets, get new users and win the platform of the future.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to say 1 thing. I kind of hesitate to do it because it's all been going so [indiscernible], but I'm really just trying to avoid work for a day with Scott over the next couple of days and having the same conversations several dozen different
componenttext: I just wanted to say 1 thing. I kind of hesitate to do it because it's all been going so [indiscernible], but I'm really just trying to avoid work for a day with Scott over the next couple of days and having the same conversations several dozen different times. Because I've had it in private, even I go down to the coffee store, I get asked by all the industries in our building. And that just a question of what's going on with our activist investors. And so I just want to take that as on and happy to talk about it privately with others. But it seems like a mistake not to address it to some decree, so let me just give you my viewpoint on this. The first thing is that I think the number of the 13 [ph] filers as well as the activist investors have raised legitimate concerns. And one part that kind of troubles me about it is that there are other long-term investors, really constructive investors, who raised some issues in a much better way. And so while we're absolutely talking to the activist investors, I think too much credit is being given to them and not enough credit is being given to our long-term investors, who have asked for change in a constructive way. They've understood kind of the subtleties and complexities of running the business and they truly have taken the time to understand what the challenges and opportunities we face. And so I feel like they're getting the short end of the stick when they really pull the weight and supporting the company over the longer period. Many of my problems with sort of some of the more activist investors is that their focus is extremely short-term and somewhat simplistic. They just ignore some of the complexities of running a business. And let's just get -- lighting up for a second and then I'll return to be more serious, but let me just tell you what my concern is. Is that if you sit on the outside and have lots of good ideas, either give me this oir that for the better or why things should move more quickly, as a matter of fact, if you turn on sports radio or political talk radio, on sports radio, you can hear thousands of people who look at the coach or General Manager, but the ownership is done differently. And I worry about that thing. I watched the game last that, I have a million ideas of what the coach should do, but I don't actually have to do the job. And so in a nutshell, my concern is people who I guess essentially want to turn Autodesk into a men's warehouse. Look, I don't think I need people turn this into men's warehouse and potentially do damage to the company. I don't think they meant to screw it up, but I think they have some simplistic views, and what troubles me is that we see those things that are expressed in our business. Actually, I got a little funny stories. I look up in mens warehouse the other day and they changed the name and the company and the symbol and what I thought was interesting is changing the name makes it actually hard to track the pricing and how it performs. But the symbol is a little bit of a telltale sign. You just look at it, it's spelled T U R D. It's actually T L R D, but it's sort of what it looks and it's probably more like it. So let me just try to end this on a more serious note. We are talking to the activists, we would like to shift the conversation to the activist investors to a more constructive dialogue. There is certainly a possibility that together, we can do that. And most importantly, I just want to say thank you to our long-term shareholders, they understood what the challenges are. They have really the fantastic opportunities that we have. Thanks.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, operator. Good afternoon. Thank you for joining our conference call to discuss the results of our fourth quarter and full year fiscal 2016. Also on the line is Carl Bass, our CEO; and Scott Herren, our CFO. Today's conference call is being broadca
componenttext:
Thanks, operator. Good afternoon. Thank you for joining our conference call to discuss the results of our fourth quarter and full year fiscal 2016. Also on the line is Carl Bass, our CEO; and Scott Herren, our CFO. Today's conference call is being broadcast live via webcast. In addition, a replay of this call will be available at autodesk.com/investor. As noted in our press release, we have published our prepared remarks on our website in advance of this call. Those remarks are intended to serve in place of extended formal comments, and we will not repeat them on this call.
During the course of this conference call, we will make forward-looking statements regarding future events and the anticipated future performance of the company, such as our guidance for the first quarter and full year fiscal 2017; our long-term financial model guidance; the factors we use to estimate our guidance, including currency headwinds; expectations regarding our restructuring; our transition to new business models; our market opportunities and strategies; and trends for various products, geographies and industries. We caution you that such statements reflect the best judgment based on factors currently known to us and that actual events or results could differ materially. Please refer to the documents we file from time to time with the SEC, specifically our Form 10-K for the fiscal year 2015; our Form 10-Q for the periods ended April 30, July 31 and October 31, 2015; and our current reports on Form 8-K, including the Form 8-K furnished with today's press release and prepared remarks. Those documents contain and identify important risks and other factors that may cause our actual results to differ from those contained in our forward-looking statements. Forward-looking statements made during the call are being made as of today. If this call is replayed or reviewed after today, the information presented during the call may not contain current or accurate information. Autodesk disclaims any obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements. We will provide guidance on today's call but will not provide any further guidance or updates on our performance during the quarter unless we do so in a public forum.
During the call, we will also discuss non-GAAP financial measures. These non-GAAP measures are not prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles. A reconciliation of our GAAP and non-GAAP results is provided in today's press release, prepared remarks and on the Investor Relations section of our website. We will quote a number of numeric or growth changes as we discuss our financial performance, and unless otherwise noted, each such reference represents a year-on-year comparison. 
And now I'd like to turn the call over to Carl.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
