componenttext: Just as a follow-up to that question on new model subs, at the Analyst Day, you guys shared that, I think, 40% of the desktop subs were new to Autodesk. Do you have any update on what those look like as you look back over the year in terms of new customers -- net new customers to you on the subs?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we don't have anything that we can update you on yet.
componenttext: No, we don't have anything that we can update you on yet.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I wouldn't suspect there's any change there. But bear in mind, there's a couple of statistics there. One is within desktop, like how many of the new desktop customers are net new to Autodesk. The other is, and this is really where the future lies, you
componenttext: No, I wouldn't suspect there's any change there. But bear in mind, there's a couple of statistics there. One is within desktop, like how many of the new desktop customers are net new to Autodesk. The other is, and this is really where the future lies, you remember some of the statistics we have on the cloud products, but they are overwhelmingly net new customers that are coming to Autodesk. Now it's still a small number today, but as you look further out into the future, that's -- we talk about TAM expansion, we talk about the upside of making not just the business model change, meaning the pricing change, but the platform shift to the cloud. And that platform shift really drives. We see a lot of net new customers to Autodesk and it expands our TAM.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, if you're looking at this carefully, just to put it in size and why we defer to the existing base, our cloud products that are doing well are in the tens of thousands as opposed to all other things, which are in the millions. So the growth rates can
componenttext: Yes, if you're looking at this carefully, just to put it in size and why we defer to the existing base, our cloud products that are doing well are in the tens of thousands as opposed to all other things, which are in the millions. So the growth rates can be high, the percentage of any particular characteristic can be high, but we're still comparing 10,000. On the other hand, 10,000 is growing at 50% a year, so it's turning into real numbers.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just following up, you mentioned you'll be meeting with the channel next week, and you mentioned the Collections product as one sort of new offering for them. Any other changes that you expect to see in the channel this year? And anything related
componenttext: And then just following up, you mentioned you'll be meeting with the channel next week, and you mentioned the Collections product as one sort of new offering for them. Any other changes that you expect to see in the channel this year? And anything related to the reorgans and spending cuts that are going to change anything on that side?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think what you'll see on the -- yes, they will see Collections and they will hear about that. They'll hear about new products, some of the improvements in the back office, which would improve the efficiency of their businesses as well. There's alw
componenttext: Well, I think what you'll see on the -- yes, they will see Collections and they will hear about that. They'll hear about new products, some of the improvements in the back office, which would improve the efficiency of their businesses as well. There's always minor tweaks to the programs we have in place. But I don't see anything hugely different coming out of it. Just one more year, our partners follow us closely, as you know, and we've been working pretty closely. I would be disappointed if anything we said was a huge surprise to our partners.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Matt Hedberg from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Matt Hedberg from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Dan Bergstrom for Matt Hedberg. I'd say, to build on Heather's question and even Steve's, with the fiscal year '17 free cash flow moving higher and with the updated targets, should we still think of free cash flow bottoming in fiscal year '17? And
componenttext: This is Dan Bergstrom for Matt Hedberg. I'd say, to build on Heather's question and even Steve's, with the fiscal year '17 free cash flow moving higher and with the updated targets, should we still think of free cash flow bottoming in fiscal year '17? And then thinking back to the mentioned free cash flow glide path chart from Analyst Day, is there a quarter or year you'd point to when free cash flow would start to diverge from that chart and move more towards the updated targets?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Dan, I would say, fiscal '17 still looks like the bottom for free cash flow. Fiscal '18 still looks like the bottom for net cash versus net debt. So that -- I don't think that's changed. I think the hard part about pointing to the quarter is that is
componenttext: Yes, Dan, I would say, fiscal '17 still looks like the bottom for free cash flow. Fiscal '18 still looks like the bottom for net cash versus net debt. So that -- I don't think that's changed. I think the hard part about pointing to the quarter is that is the nadir, that is the actual bottom. There's linearity within a quarter. It has such a huge impact on free cash flow when you take these 90-day snapshots. If we just talked about the linearity of Q4, which was a strong quarter from any dimension, but because of the linearity, we saw a lot of the sales that came in, in Q4, come into that third month and depressed our recorded cash -- free cash flows for Q4 by about $95 million, which now have shifted from Q4 and into Q1. So I think that with linearity being such a large variable there, it's really hard to say if this quarter definitively is going to be the bottom. But think of it as happening in fiscal '17 from a free cash flow standpoint, and then from an accumulated cash standpoint, think of that as fiscal '18.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Brent Thill from UBS.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Brent Thill from UBS.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Carl, I think maybe your answer is going to be you're going to have to wait to my question. But when you think about the Suite bundles that you're going to have available, you have a very complex lineup of products, and I think everyone is just trying to
componenttext: Carl, I think maybe your answer is going to be you're going to have to wait to my question. But when you think about the Suite bundles that you're going to have available, you have a very complex lineup of products, and I think everyone is just trying to understand how you think about directionally the number of bundles, what they look like. Is this just something we're going to have to wait? Or is there any hints in terms of how we should think about that?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no, no. Yes, you don't have to wait that long. I mean, we're going to be rolling them out to our partners. But basically, it looks like -- think of it as a couple per industry. Kind of in rough terms, I mean, I can give you a lot more details, but jus
componenttext: No, no, no. Yes, you don't have to wait that long. I mean, we're going to be rolling them out to our partners. But basically, it looks like -- think of it as a couple per industry. Kind of in rough terms, I mean, I can give you a lot more details, but just think of it as a couple per industry. And then there will be a handful of stand-alone products that generally are in different price points and different levels of sophistication and complexity that -- so for example, some of our complex stimulation tools like Moldflow, we're not going to wrap into a bundle because it just doesn't hit broad enough section of the base. So the things that we're putting into the Collections are the things that we think will be broadly used and we're going to put together a couple offerings in each of our 3 large industries that we serve.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The way to think about it is the goal is, first of all, to simplify, and so you'll see us bring down what is a fairly large menu of offerings into a much simpler set of offerings. Point one. And the second is to drive consumption, to build those bundles i
componenttext: The way to think about it is the goal is, first of all, to simplify, and so you'll see us bring down what is a fairly large menu of offerings into a much simpler set of offerings. Point one. And the second is to drive consumption, to build those bundles in a way that drives broader consumption, much like we see with the T-Flex on the very high end.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And this is a follow-up. Carl, there's -- many of the analysts on the call have covered software for close to 2 decades. It's been rare you see a 7-year out-goal and -- on the free cash flow number. And just going looking at history, you never achie
componenttext: Okay. And this is a follow-up. Carl, there's -- many of the analysts on the call have covered software for close to 2 decades. It's been rare you see a 7-year out-goal and -- on the free cash flow number. And just going looking at history, you never achieved 3 quarters of $1 billion of cash flow, yet you're giving a $2.5 billion goal. I guess, I know this is an aspirational target and there's a lot of things that could change, but what gives you the confidence at this point to do that when historically, that's -- these long-term targets have been tough to hit?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, good question, really, Brent. I mean, I think it's partially what I just answered is that we start -- so for example, we start building a model in which almost all of the revenue comes off the balance sheet. So just starting with that idea that quart
componenttext: Yes, good question, really, Brent. I mean, I think it's partially what I just answered is that we start -- so for example, we start building a model in which almost all of the revenue comes off the balance sheet. So just starting with that idea that quarters used to start at 0 and will now start at 80 or 90 or 95 is different. You will also be able to look at things like the churn and see the renewal rates and extrapolate from there. So to the extent that -- and we generally haven't gone out that far, but people really didn't understand the dynamic of this. And so we were just trying to put it in perspective. I mean, to the extent that you want to discount FY '23, feel free to. It's way in the future. I think the FY '20 is there. The problem we had and really the reason why we gave details around FY '23 is because FY '20 or FY '21 is still so much in the steep part of the curve. And so if we -- when we were doing that and only talking about FY '20, people were saying, is that the terminal? Is it the terminal cash flow? Is it the terminal EPS? Is it the terminal operating margin? And it wasn't. And just to the extent now that traditional financial metrics are going to go down predictably as a result of how we account for this, it's just as certain that they come up on the other side. So I'm totally fine with people wanting to discount FY '23. We just wanted to make sure that people understood that, that's what our model looks like. And I think if you back off it and look, we've impressed. There are some people who think we should be able to get a lot more. There are some people who get to less. But you can then look at it in a pretty reasonable way about -- thinking about the number of subscribers. Because remember, if anything, we have been attacked for our ARPS. So there's not a lot of assumption about the ARPS going up, so it really is all about subscribers and then ARR really translates directly to revenues. So put whatever discounts you want on it, Brent.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Steve Koenig from Wedbush Securities.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Steve Koenig from Wedbush Securities.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you a little bit about the long-term trajectory when it comes to thinking about new users. And I know that there's definitely definitional issues there. But if we suppose that out of your 650k seat sales run rate, let's just say for the sa
componenttext: I wanted to ask you a little bit about the long-term trajectory when it comes to thinking about new users. And I know that there's definitely definitional issues there. But if we suppose that out of your 650k seat sales run rate, let's just say for the sake of argument, half of those are kind of new users versus half are people that are active but weren't regularly paying and maybe buying a new license or something, if I -- unless I mangled that, if I'm thinking about that the right way, if we can assume that, what happens to that new user addition number as you move through the transition? Can that 300k go up due to adding pirated users? It probably should go up -- you should be adding those old license users as subscriptions, but then those become renewals later in time. And so how can we think about the unit sales and the seat sales as we move along the transition?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We would hope to see those continually going up. We've been pretty modest in our assumption. But you're right, you have the old subscribers. And remember, the definitional issue just really gets to this thing of a user could be in a different company
componenttext: Yes. We would hope to see those continually going up. We've been pretty modest in our assumption. But you're right, you have the old subscribers. And remember, the definitional issue just really gets to this thing of a user could be in a different company but they have been a user before, and let's just ignore that for a second. But the old subscribers would be there. Piracy, we think, this will put a significant dent in casual piracy. And as we said the new offerings are the places where we're getting new customers. So come at this a different way. We talk about it sometimes as TAM expansion. We talk about it as new users. I referenced 100 million people in manufacturing and construction who didn't have a need for many of the tools we previously sold, but they do now, whether that's BIM 360 or PLM 360. Those are new users. Those new users may be inside of existing customers or they may be in new accounts. But we didn't give you an indication. Many of these products are relatively high. In almost all cases, the majority of the customers that are doing it are not traditional customers. The other thing that I think is really important, and I know you guys do not want to bake too much into your model, but we're running a business not a spreadsheet. And in our world, the investments we've made in going to cloud-based engineering tools has led us to have a leadership position in that. We deeply believe that the future of all software is in the cloud and in mobile and it opens up big markets. I've always believed, for people who invest in Autodesk, this is one of the fundamental tenets you should believe in. There are less difficult ways to get there, but we think the business model transition starts the curve we just talked about with Brent. But if that is going to continue into the out-years, that's based on the fact that we expand into new markets, get new users and win the platform of the future.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016

componenttext: And that concludes our question-and-answer session. I would like to turn the conference back over to Carl Bass, CEO, for any additional comments.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I just wanted to say one thing. I kind of hesitate to do it because it's all been going so swimmingly. But I'm really just trying to avoid work for dinging Scott and I over the next couple of days in having the same conversations several dozen differ
componenttext: Yes, I just wanted to say one thing. I kind of hesitate to do it because it's all been going so swimmingly. But I'm really just trying to avoid work for dinging Scott and I over the next couple of days in having the same conversations several dozen different times. Because I've had it in private, even as I go down to the coffee store, I get asked by all the investors in our building. And that's just a question of what's going on with our activist investors. And so I just want to take that head on and happy to talk about it privately with others, but it seems like a mistake not to address it to some degree. So let me just give you my viewpoint on this. The first thing is that I think a number of the 13D filers as well as some of the activist investors have raised legitimate concerns. And one part that kind of troubles me about it is that there are other long-term investors, really constructive investors, who have raised the same issues in a much better way. And so while we are absolutely talking to the activist investors, I think too much credit is being given to them and not enough credit is being given to our long-term investors who have asked for change in a constructive way. They've understood kind of the subtleties and complexities of running the business and they truly have taken the time to understand what the challenges and the opportunities we face. And so I feel like they're getting the short end of the stick when they've really pulled the laboring war [ph] in supporting the company over the long period. Many of my problems with sort of some of the more activist investors is that their focus is extremely short-term and somewhat simplistic. They just ignore some of the complexities of running a business. And let's just get a lighter note for a second and then I'll return to being more serious, but let me just tell you what my concern is, because it's easy to sit on the outside and have lots of good ideas, how to do this or that thing better or why things should move more quickly. As a matter of fact, if you turn on sports radio or political talk radio, on sports radio, you can hear thousands of people who know what the coach or general manager or the owner should have done differently. And I'm worried about that [indiscernible]. I watched the game last night, I had a million ideas of what the coach should do, but I didn't actually have to do the job. And so in a nutshell, my concern is people who like essentially want to turn Autodesk into Men's Wearhouse. If you look, I don't think any of the people who got involved in Men's Wearhouse intentionally meant to do damage to the company. I don't think they meant to screw it up, but I think they had some simplistic views. And what troubles me is seeing those same views expressed about our business. Actually, I got one little funny story here. I looked up Men's Wearhouse the other day, I was trying -- and they changed the name of the company and the symbol. And what I thought was interesting is changing the name makes it actually hard to track the price and how poorly it's performed. But the symbol is a little bit of a telltale sign because if you just look at it and squint, it's spelled T-U-R-D. It's actually T-L-R-D, but it's what it looks and there's probably more like it. So let me just try to end this on a more serious note. We are talking to the activists, we would like to shift the conversation to the active investors to a more constructive dialogue. There is certainly a possibility that together, we can do that. And most importantly, I just want to say thank you to our long-term shareholders who have understood what the challenges are. They're really the fantastic opportunities the company has. Thanks.

componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Autodesk First Quarter Fiscal Year 2017 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to hand the meeting over to David Gennarelli, Senior Director, Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, operator. Good afternoon. Thank you for joining our conference call to discuss the results of our first quarter fiscal 2017. Also on the line are Carl Bass, our CEO; and Scott Herren, our CFO. Today's conference call is being broadcast live via
componenttext:
Thanks, operator. Good afternoon. Thank you for joining our conference call to discuss the results of our first quarter fiscal 2017. Also on the line are Carl Bass, our CEO; and Scott Herren, our CFO. 
Today's conference call is being broadcast live via webcast. In addition, a replay of the call will be available at autodesk.com/investor. As noted in our press release, we have published our prepared remarks on our website in advance of this call. Those remarks are intended to serve in place of extended formal comments, and we will not repeat them on this call.
During the course of this conference call, we will make forward-looking statements regarding future events and the anticipated future performance of the company such as our guidance for the second quarter and full year fiscal 2017; our long-term financial model guidance; the factors we use to estimate our guidance, including currency headwinds; expectations regarding our restructuring; the various anticipated benefits, including predictability of revenue and reduced cost structure from our transition to new business models; our market opportunities and strategies and trends for various products, geographies and industries.
We caution you that such statements reflect our best judgment based on factors currently known to us and that actual events or results could differ materially. Please refer to the documents we file from time to time with the SEC, specifically, our Form 10-K for the fiscal year 2016; and our current reports on Form 8-K, including the Form 8-K furnished with today's press release and prepared remarks. Those documents contain and identify important risks and other factors that may cause our actual results to differ from those contained in our forward-looking statements. 
Forward-looking statements made during the call are being made as of today. If this call is replayed or reviewed after today, the information presented during the call may not contain current or accurate information. Autodesk disclaims any obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements. We will provide guidance on today's call but will not provide any further guidance or updates on our performance during the quarter unless we do so in a public forum.
During the call, we will also disclose non-GAAP financial measures. These non-GAAP measures are not prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles. A reconciliation of our GAAP and non-GAAP results is provided in today's press release, prepared remarks and on the Investor Relations section of our website. 
We will quote a number of numeric or growth changes as we discuss our financial performance, and unless otherwise noted, each such reference represents a year-on-year comparison. And now I'd like to turn the call over to Carl.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave. We had a terrific start to FY '17, with more proof points that the transition from perpetual licenses to subscription and cloud offerings is going well. We're moving steadily ahead on our 2 big initiatives: First, we are increasing the lifet
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave. We had a terrific start to FY '17, with more proof points that the transition from perpetual licenses to subscription and cloud offerings is going well. We're moving steadily ahead on our 2 big initiatives: First, we are increasing the lifetime customer value. Secondly, we're driving increased adoption of our cloud-based solutions to better serve existing customers as well as expand into I'll share more details on our Q1 results and then talk more about our view around long-term shareholder value creation before getting into our outlook for the rest of the year.
As I mentioned last quarter, the primary focus for us through the transition is driving subscriptions and annualized recurring revenue or ARR. In total, we added 132,000 net new subscriptions in the quarter. New model subscription additions more than doubled to 140,000. And while we expected maintenance subscriptions to decline, in conjunction with the end of sale of perpetual licenses on individual products at the end of Q4, total maintenance subscriptions declined by only 8,000 as our renewal [indiscernible] maintenance continues to increase. 
Q1 was the first quarter where customers no longer had the option to buy a perpetual license for individual products such as AutoCAD or AutoCAD LT. As a result, additions from product subscription, formerly known as desktop subscription, jumped dramatically by 125% sequentially and by nearly 350% year-over-year. 
Helping drive product subscription growth in Q1 was a promotion targeted at converted [indiscernible] our legacy non-subscriber base to new product subscriptions. This promotion captured legacy non-subscribers who are customers that purchased the perpetual license sometime in the past and wanted to trade in their old perpetual license for a product subscription at a discount. It turned out to be one of the most successful promotions we've ever run and contributed over 25,000 net new model subscriptions to the quarter. 
As we analyzed the data, the really interesting part was that over 50% of those taking advantage of the promotion were using versions from 7 years back or older. We've talked about the opportunity to convey the [indiscernible] of the estimated 2.8 million non-subscribers, which captures a 5-year lookback. We knew there was a meaningful number of active users beyond that 5-year lookback and this was a great validation of that point.
New model subscriptions also got a strong contribution from our enterprise flexible license or EBA customers. I mentioned on last quarter's call that in Q4, we signed up a record number of enterprise customers for these token-based or consumption style EBAs. And that because of the way we count those subscriptions, we've seen the benefit to net new subscriptions in Q1 as we did in the first quarter of last year. These EBAs contributed more than 25,000 subscription additions in Q1 this year. 
EBAs with our large enterprise customers have been a very successful component of our transition, leading to both increased subscriptions and account value while creating increased flexibility for our customers. 
We also had a record quarter for cloud subscription additions in Q1, which increased nearly 50% sequentially. BIM 360 and PLM 360 continued to lead the way but we're also having success with our other cloud products such as Shotgun, A360 and Fusion 360. 
Our cloud-based products continue to bring in new customers to Autodesk. Our newest cloud product is our IoT platform, Fusion Kinect, formerly known as SeeControl, a service that helps manufacturers and system integrators connect, analyze, control and manage remotely, which is gaining traction. change the Cad, CAM and PLM markets with cloud-based products, we're doing the same with Internet of Things, enabling our customers to easily incorporate IoT capabilities into their projects. 
In Q1, we landed a 6-figure IoT deal with an industrial manufacturing company and [indiscernible] the competing head-to-head against other well-known competitors. This is an exceptional win because the customer is considered a pioneer in IT and as making connected products as part of their core business strategy for several years. 
It's important to note that our channel partners are fully engaged with our subscription model. 63% of new model subscription additions came through our channel partners compared to just 27% in Q1 last year. We're also excited about the number of subscriptions coming through our eStore, which have more than doubled from Q1 last year. Our total direct sales increased to 25% in the first quarter. That's up from just 15% 2 years ago, and it's still in the early days for our eStore.
The [indiscernible] new model subscriptions fueled a 76% year-on-year constant currency increase in new model ARR. Total recurring revenue jumped to 70% of our total liquidity revenues compared to 53% last quarter. Total ARR growth was 12% at constant currency year-on-year. Remember, when the value of the total ARR growth relative to our long-term target that this number would build over the next 3 quarters as new model becomes an increasingly large component of total ARR, so we are very confident with the growth we experienced here in Q1.
Another metric that we've talked [indiscernible] about has been unit volume. When comparing our unit volume to the first quarter last year, it was in line with our expectations. On the expense side, we are diligently controlling our spending. As a result of the restructuring action we took early in the quarter, our total spend decreased more than 2 percentage points year-on-year. We are continuing to make structural changes that allow us to spend less yet focus on our key initiatives. We are carefully balancing the need for financial discipline with a need to invest to drive long-term health of the company. 
Overall, we are very pleased with the Q1 results, which are a great start to the year and [indiscernible] confident that the transition is working for our customers, our partners and Autodesk. 
[indiscernible] to the end of Q2 when we start perpetual licenses for Suites and become fully immersed in the subscription model. Another exciting factor about Q3 is that we begin selling [indiscernible] as our next generation of Suites called Collections. 
We [indiscernible] customers until next week, but I will give you a little preview. Collections will be the most convenient way for customers to access a wide selection of both our desktop software and our cloud services. We're significantly reducing complexity by offering just 3 collections: 1 for 1 for manufacturing and 1 for . The value for our customers is tremendous and well exceeds our Premium Suite. We're offering single user and multi-user access and choices of different rates that fit their needs. 
Suites have been a tremendous success since we launched them over 5 years ago, and Collections will take it to the next level by giving greater flexibility to our customers and increasing the lifetime value for us. 
[indiscernible] touched on last quarter and that's about what we're doing to create long-term value for our shareholders. [indiscernible] because I see that where we're ultimately aiming to accomplish, which is position Autodesk to lead the next-generation design [indiscernible] somewhat in the noise of quarterly financial results. 
Our transition is really happening on 2 vectors. The first is the business model pricing transition that is happening now, where our customers are needing to churn-based subscriptions. Over the next 3 years, we expect this process to move to a highly predictable model and significant increase in the value our customers get from our products. 
It's important this model change we are simplifying our entire go-to-market strategy to align with the concept of being an all-subscription company, the result [indiscernible] meaningful increases in the business we do directly with our customers at the enterprise and e-commerce levels. In of these changes ultimately reduce our cost structure and increase how effectively we serve our customers. 
The second vector of our transition is how we are building platforms to exploit the cloud and dramatically expand the size of our market opportunities. [indiscernible] we've made in this area started over 3 years ago allowed us to get a sizable lead on our current competitors as well as funded startups. We've seen the platform shift moving before. Incumbents would slowly become less relevant while the world changes around that. We're to secure the future of Autodesk and our new cloud-based products are already the undisputed leaders in their respective categories. 
It's not just about making [indiscernible] design tools. It's about market expansion. Mobile and cloud technologies are opening up significant opportunities in areas of construction and manufacturing that are completely new to Autodesk. Again, our framework for creating long-term shareholder value is to increase the lifetime value of every customer, change our cost structure and [indiscernible] each customers and best cloud and mobile-based products and services in the industry as the underlying platform shifts to the cloud. While many people are focused on the business model shift, leadership position in the cloud leads to a long-term sustainable competitive advantage.
Now turning to our Q2 and full year outlook. I mentioned on last quarter's call while the current fiscal year is the most unique in the company's history as we complete the transition from perpetual licenses to subscriptions at the end of Q2. None of the traditional seasonality patterns or sales metrics will be applicable, nor will year-over-year [indiscernible] traditional metrics be helpful in understanding how we are performing through the transition. Similar to our Q1 [ph] hitting the low end of the revenue range while exceeding our subscription guidance is a desirable outcome for the year. 
Our view of the macroeconomic environment impact on our business hasn't changed since last quarter or the past several quarters for that matter. The conditions have been most of the emerging markets have been difficult, but most of the mature markets have been relatively good. As we evaluated our strong Q1 results, we didn't see any meaningful change in the demand environment. 
For the end of sale of suites here in Q2, we expect will resemble what we saw in Q4 with the end of sale for individual products. In other words, we're expecting some surge activity but not a lot. Remember that our unit volume and revenue contribution from Suites is much lower than our individual products, and we've already seen a significant shift in Suites customers to the new model. 
While this is good news in terms of moving them to a higher value offering now and not having to convince them later, it down our expectations for a surge in value at the end of this quarter. Also while the targeting legacy customers successful in Q1, we will not be running that promo here in Q2.
Q3 may be our first quarter of subscription-only sales across the board and will likely experience sequential slowdown. That's when you can expect to see promotions aimed at legacy customers again. If you're not modeling a sequential decline for Q3 already, you should be. And if consistent with our expectations for the full year, which are unchanged. And Q4 should begin to show more normal sales trends in our near subscription-only model. 
We made a slight adjustment to our FY '17 outlook for EPS based on our revised tax assumption for the year. Otherwise, we remain comfortable with our full year outlook for FY '17 and our long-term goals of growing our subscription base by a 20% CAGR over the next 4 years, which will drive a 24% CAGR in ARR. 
We remain committed to keeping spend grade roughly flat to slightly down this year and flat in FY '18. And coupled with our top line projections, we see a path to free cash flow of roughly $6 per share in FY '20 and $11 per share in FY '23. 
To wrap things up, our business model transition is in full swing now and exceeding expectations. We're very excited to be another major step further along in the transition, and by the second half of this year, we will fully be in a subscription-only model. 
Customers [indiscernible] model subscriptions and the cloud. At the same time, we're driving higher lifetime value, simplifying our offerings and our go-to-market activities and significantly increasing our market opportunity as we meet the next wave of design and engineering software to the cloud. We have a clear vision and plan for creating a more predictable, recurring and profitable business in the years to come.
Operator, we'd now like to open the call up for questions.

Q1 is usually [indiscernible]. Q2 and Q3 [indiscernible] and then Q4 comes out as the usual seasonality pattern. componenttext: Yes, and Saket, in terms of the split between products and Suites, I know you know this, but the AutoCAD and AutoCAD LT are, by far, the highest volume. So we look at unit volumes. They dominate that as well. Suites are higher priced but significantly lower volume.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, got it. And as my follow-up, Carl, one of the interesting things that you mentioned was a fair number of the non-subscribers that converted this, I guess, this quarter were on tools that were older than 7 years. And I think the 2.8 million that we
componenttext: Got it, got it. And as my follow-up, Carl, one of the interesting things that you mentioned was a fair number of the non-subscribers that converted this, I guess, this quarter were on tools that were older than 7 years. And I think the 2.8 million that we've talked about historically is for -- or for non-subscribers that are on tools 5 years or less. So I guess, the question is what will that number look like if you included a couple more years of sort of non-subscribers? And as you build a couple more data points, how do you feel about that 30% conversion that you've talked about within that base?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so let me -- that's a great question. And I know it's got a lot of attention, so let me just back up a little bit and give you a more holistic view of meeting people to subscription and then try to place of the 2.8 million into context. So as we were
componenttext: Yes, so let me -- that's a great question. And I know it's got a lot of attention, so let me just back up a little bit and give you a more holistic view of meeting people to subscription and then try to place of the 2.8 million into context. So as we were looking at building out the new model that would be subscription-only, we basically said that there were 3 pools of people that we could draw from: one were the non-subscribers. The second were the non-payers or the pirates. And the third, I'll just call the nonusers, basically people who are not using software or using competitive software. And share shift would be [indiscernible]. 3 different distinct pools with different dynamics. One of the questions came up frequently was, "Okay, what is the size of the people who bought products that aren't on subscription?" And what we said is our new model, or [indiscernible] model, we were looking to add about 800,000 subscribers to the total. From this collection of sources. People wanted to know the size of the -- wanted to know the size of each of these relative segments. To think about it. On the non-subscribers, one data point we give you there's only just 1 was that in the last 5 years and [indiscernible] relatively constant, which is why we chose it is a convenient data point. There were 2.8 million people who had bought that had an attached subscription. We put a caveat around that. It's some people may no longer be users and no longer be actively using it. They may have come back in by buying a new license. They may have joined a different firm. They could have passed away for all we know. But we wanted to give a size to it. There were clearly people beyond that 5 years who are still using software as evidenced by that. So it's just an indication and if you look, it's interesting and somewhat obvious in at least retrospect. But if you look at the legacy results, more people that were back 6 and 7 years that in years, 1, 2 and 3. The news around 7 years and [indiscernible] distribution. So that should give you an indication of what goes on in that case. So it is bigger. And what we had said is we thought we could convert 30%. So taking into account how many people were no longer active or the new model would not appeal to them, we thought we could convert 30% of the base. And that's what we're indicating our assumption in the model. The second one is and I think people want to look at this and miss out on the dynamics as we move to a more connected experience for our customers is that right now, somewhere around half or slightly more than half of the usage of our products in the world is by people who do not pay for it. Once again, you got to pay a discount on how many people will actually pay for when they are forced to. But at least, these many people don't take software they use it as the ones who do. And then the third one, which I did not rule out is an important contribution to the subscription additions are the people who are using competitive products. I think what you've done to lead the way in cloud-based engineering software is going to be very attractive and will be a source of [indiscernible] customers for many of the legacy providers who has frankly kind of moving the software to the cloud. So sorry for the very long-winded answer to your question, but I thought it would -- [indiscernible]  And i just wanted to try to put it in the broader context.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Carl, with you and then finish with Scott with a follow-up. I thought it was very useful that you highlighted the technology and product vector for strategy and not just a lot of change. So on that point, could you talk about how you were thinking about t
componenttext: Carl, with you and then finish with Scott with a follow-up. I thought it was very useful that you highlighted the technology and product vector for strategy and not just a lot of change. So on that point, could you talk about how you were thinking about the timing of delivery of new technology over time? In other words, for example, is being updated seemingly on a quarterly basis, so back in December in a year, we heard that AutoCAD may go to a more than 12-month cycle for major releases. And could you talk about what you think the relevance is of the schedule of various products is to sustaining the flywheel of the subscription model? And one almost obviously missing brand in your portfolio is, let's call it, Revit 360. You've got all kinds of other 360s, but you don't have a Revit 360. Is that something that would make sense for you?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So generally, the [indiscernible] updates is inversely proportional to the maturity of the product just broadly speaking, if you were to look and say a very mature product like AutoCAD needs frequent updates, products like any of the 360, like Fusion
componenttext: Yes. So generally, the [indiscernible] updates is inversely proportional to the maturity of the product just broadly speaking, if you were to look and say a very mature product like AutoCAD needs frequent updates, products like any of the 360, like Fusion 360 gets updated relatively frequently. If you follow Fusion there's weekly and biweekly small updates and certainly every month, there's an update with significant functionality. We have continued that. In some ways, it's not the overall quantity of stuff delivered. One of the thing that changes in this [indiscernible] is really the frequency. And I think it changes is also the digestibility. I did [indiscernible] a year versus having dozens of small snacks. And a little bit what this allows us to do with our newer products is have not only us deploy the software more effectively, but our customers more easily discover what's in it and put it to use as quickly as possible. So kind of continue on that kind of cadence of the newer cloud-based products would be frequently updated. The other ones will be a little bit slower but both the traditional products and the new cloud services, we need to be thought of differently as connected experiences, which now allow us to do things in the ongoing use and in the update that just not possible before. As a matter of fact, even when you look at some of the data were just reporting on question, a bunch of that comes from frequent connectivity.

componenttext: Let me just answer your yes, there's a bunch of work going on, on online stuff the industry. headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me answer that, the second part first. I am working on that. I realize that the way we do it is accurate in terms of accounting standard, the way we do it today but confusing from a modeling standpoint. So one of the things that we're working on
componenttext: Yes, let me answer that, the second part first. I am working on that. I realize that the way we do it is accurate in terms of accounting standard, the way we do it today but confusing from a modeling standpoint. So one of the things that we're working on is trying to simplify the way we categorize revenue as it comes out of the and hit the P&L such that even we can keep maintenance separate from what I'll call new model subscriptions separate from license and other. That's not ready yet but that's something that is implied. And I think it will be a very investor-friendly move when we can make that. First question on capacity, we see the cut -- so we built the entitlement engine. We are -- as you think about it, it's a multi-phase process, right? You've got build the capability on the back end of than each product has to build in the capability to recognize the new back-end. And use that as a way of turning it on so that they can get access to it and there is products ramp up the capacity on the back end gets tested. So any problems at this point as we ramp of the new model subscription fairly rapidly. And I think they're -- it's now a question of absorption and adoption of the new models.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Sterling, we're not seeing a lot of that activity right now. We've talked about the path that we'll head down to make that happen. As you know, it's a higher price to convert if you're an existing maintenance customer. It's higher price to convert ov
componenttext: Yes, Sterling, we're not seeing a lot of that activity right now. We've talked about the path that we'll head down to make that happen. As you know, it's a higher price to convert if you're an existing maintenance customer. It's higher price to convert over to the new model offerings. And so what we've talked about is driving higher value into the desktop subscription offerings that make that something that besides being required to do it as you buy additional capacity, there's [indiscernible  you've already got the existing perpetual license and maintenance attached to it. So it's not -- the reduction is not driven by conversions. And by the way, the reduction of 8,000 subs, the net reduction of 8,000 subs on maintenance was purely expected. It's more driven by just taking a very high renewal rate, the one that's not 100% and multiplying it times a very big number of maintenance installed base.

componenttext: Got you. And then as a follow-up, looking at sequential change in revenue by the area, it looks like AEC did not get impacted as much as some of the others. Is that just natural fact maybe there's more Suite revenue in AEC versus the other 2 buckets or the other couple of buckets?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was looking at the sort of numbers and the subs numbers. And it as really nice quarter, as you guys have noted, in terms of adding those new model subs. But one of the things I noticed is that the business [indiscernible] and some numbers is so much hig
componenttext: I was looking at the sort of numbers and the subs numbers. And it as really nice quarter, as you guys have noted, in terms of adding those new model subs. But one of the things I noticed is that the business [indiscernible] and some numbers is so much higher than the ARR number. The [indiscernible] average recurring revenue per subscription is going down for the new model subs. And I think it's down something in the order of about 20% year-on-year. Can you talk to us a little bit about what's driving that down? Is it mix shifts? Is it sort of promotional pricing? And what should we expect on a going-forward basis is that going to settle out at some point? Is that going to turn up once we have the Suites go fully to subscription? How should we be thinking about that trend line on ARPS on a go-forward basis?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Keith. It really is a mixed driven. As an over the end of sale for perpetual licenses at the end of Q4, a lot of the new model subs that we added this quarter, of course, are the low-end models, right? So it's LT and AutoCAD. And so as those come on
componenttext: Sure, Keith. It really is a mixed driven. As an over the end of sale for perpetual licenses at the end of Q4, a lot of the new model subs that we added this quarter, of course, are the low-end models, right? So it's LT and AutoCAD. And so as those come online and the way they measure ARR is we sum the recurring revenue for the entire quarter, multiply that by 4, and that's what the company's ARR. So the linearity in the quarter is one effect but mix is a bigger effect. Actually, you see the same thing and maintenance going the reverse direction. As there are fewer AutoCAD LT and AutoCAD maintenance subs, probably already done the math you see the ARPS is going up slightly on the maintenance side but coming down on you model strictly a matter of mix. That will reverse, of course, when we get to the second half and into next year, and we return to a mix that has an equivalent representation of suites as well as you've seen historically.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And remember if you just make it back to what we did around the long-term model, we've always said that mix is going to drive this over a longer period of time. In particular as we add the cloud subscriptions, we've always kind of suggested that low to mi
componenttext: And remember if you just make it back to what we did around the long-term model, we've always said that mix is going to drive this over a longer period of time. In particular as we add the cloud subscriptions, we've always kind of suggested that low to mid-single digits was the increase that you've seen in ARPS along the longer period of time. And so I wouldn't say there's anything there that's out of the ordinary or outside the bounds of the model that we have right now.

componenttext: Sure. So first of all, I need to congratulate anybody from Davidson. We all are very happy here in the Bay Area after. [indiscernible] I know second favorite. Secondly, I would prefer to move them to one of the new product subscriptions. Hopefully, one of the industry collections. As they do better for them and were valuable to us that will be a nice move. The collections going forward will have the number of cloud services, including the consumption-based models built into them. So that would be away for customers to become more familiar, more comfortable and hopefully more desirous of more cloud functionality. [indiscernible] like a lot of the cloud stuff is really reaching new segments. The cloud mobile combination, for example, that's allowing us to do and if you look at the products, BIM 360 and PLM 360, I mean, reaching [indiscernible] enterprise or parts of industry that would not otherwise accessible to us. [indiscernible] 3- to 5-year period, I think almost all of the software run online and really just have different versions and other [indiscernible] in a browser on a mobile device or as an installed application on the desktop they will get to their on their device of choice.

I'm assuming that part of the game plan or roadmap here will be to introduce some mobile applications to some of your desktop subscribers. When might we start to see timing-wise some of that incremental functionality being offered from a cloud to desktop subscribers?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so it's starting right now. I say, Q3 through the end of the year, you will increasingly see cloud services that are available to all of our subscribers. There'll be packaged differently. Many of them will be done on a consumption basis. So, for exam
componenttext: Yes, so it's starting right now. I say, Q3 through the end of the year, you will increasingly see cloud services that are available to all of our subscribers. There'll be packaged differently. Many of them will be done on a consumption basis. So, for example, you will be [indiscernible] consumption plans [indiscernible] models in order to tap in the power of the cloud. So for example, visualization, analysis, being able to run many of these computing kinds of jobs on the cloud side is going to be a part of the what of the year and will continue to roll it out [indiscernible] really good pickup in this. People the preceding this and sometimes people forget how computing [indiscernible] are. So instead of setting up a job and going for a cup of coffee, people are now able to set up a job and cloud and then continue working. And so this has been a big productivity boost. Customers are really liking it. They're already doing affirmative visualization and [indiscernible] to see a pickup in analysis and simulation end [indiscernible] that will continue. The other place where we've seen a cloud-based that's really important is the second, [indiscernible] about the cloud, which is all around collaboration and coordination. And those are services that are not only available for just the new cloud-based products but actually available for the desktop products as those people are kind of kinds of communication needs as anyone else trying to build products.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And to the point on mobile in particular, we've got BIM 360 docs out there. And so if you think of a job site, what you don't see anymore is the guys walking around with a big bundle of blueprints under their arm. They're using ruggedized mobile devices o
componenttext: And to the point on mobile in particular, we've got BIM 360 docs out there. And so if you think of a job site, what you don't see anymore is the guys walking around with a big bundle of blueprints under their arm. They're using ruggedized mobile devices on the site to do both view capabilities, to look at the logistics understand what needs to get done went to be workflow around conflict of that come up in the field [indiscernible] envisioned during the design phase. So we already have apps out there that are leveraging mobility in particular. As we think about the TAM expansion and construction, in particular, I think it goes heavily toward that space, toward the mobile space.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 19, 2016

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: They are. We actually see subscription, both attach rate for where we still have remaining perpetual license sales going up and the renewal of those going up. It makes sense given that if you have decided you want a perpetual license and you want to stay
componenttext: They are. We actually see subscription, both attach rate for where we still have remaining perpetual license sales going up and the renewal of those going up. It makes sense given that if you have decided you want a perpetual license and you want to stay on perpetual license, if you follow-up maintenance and get back on. And so you know you'll need to update that. You know to make it compatible with the latest per newer versions of companion software that you're working with us, so we're seeing both attach rate and renewal rates on maintenance improved.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 19, 2016

componenttext: One thing you'll see going forward and we'll report on it as more data comes in is the new product subscriptions. I think you will see -- I mean, this is my best guess at the time, you'll see differential rates between the differing term lengths that we have because I think some people choose term lengths based on a day [indiscernible]. How they want to be but many do it because of the spike in demand. And so I think you will see differential rates, for example, between annual and quarterly. And as we get data that makes it statistically significant you will report out on that.

componenttext: This is filling in for Heather. So you had your biggest increase in new model ARR this quarter at over $50 million. Mentioned a few things that helps like the channel contribution. Just wondering what clicked in the channel this quarter. And overall, would you call the top drivers of new model ARR this quarter that may have not been helping in the past.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Shakeel, I'll start and Carl, you can jump in. Obviously, the first biggest driver of new model ARR for the quarter was the end of sale of perpetual at the end of the prior quarter. So we talked about unit volume being right in line with our expectations.
componenttext: Shakeel, I'll start and Carl, you can jump in. Obviously, the first biggest driver of new model ARR for the quarter was the end of sale of perpetual at the end of the prior quarter. So we talked about unit volume being right in line with our expectations. To the extent that they -- that those customers were looking for auto-cutter AutoCAD LT that drove a huge amount of the increase of 140,000 new model sub adds. I'd say the other piece that Carl's already talked about but also affected in particular on desktop is the success of the promo that we have that targeted legacy users of the software that didn't have a subscription attached. Those would be the 2 biggest drivers of the new model subs for the quarter.

componenttext: Sure. As I think we called out in and I'm sure we called out in prepared remarks, around about 80% of that cash, of course, is offshore, given our tax structure, it would be quite extent and bring it back home have to get it to do a share repurchase. mentioned in the past that is our business model changes and as tax legislation around the world is somewhat implied, we are looking at overall operating structure, and that will have an impact on tax structure. But as we stand today with that cash trapped offshore and the current tax we've got would be a very proposition to bring it home.

componenttext: Well, there are slightly different stages of maturity, but we showed good growth in all of the products. We're in the very early stages and by comparison as explosive growth. I mean, each one of these is taking off. We -- look at it a little bit more fine grain. A handful of 360 products our targeted at collaboration operation and users in-kind of clumps has company or company [indiscernible]. System come on some of the design engineering products are more small teams [indiscernible]. But across the board, we're seeing good adoption of the cloud products. And a great response from customers. If anyone wants to do kind of the equivalent of channel checks on a product side, there's a huge amount of information out there on social media about the acceptance and of people are just becoming aware that there's a whole new generation of products out there.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 19, 2016

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as a follow-up, Carl, you talked about BIM 360. You're talking about some of the addressable markets, which aren't significantly above the non-subscriber base and all that kind of stuff. So if I forward and look at BIM 360, say 3 years or 4 years from
componenttext: And as a follow-up, Carl, you talked about BIM 360. You're talking about some of the addressable markets, which aren't significantly above the non-subscriber base and all that kind of stuff. So if I forward and look at BIM 360, say 3 years or 4 years from now, first of all, when do you think you'll hit the sweet spot or inflection point on BIM 360? And how big could this be say in 5 years?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, what you can look at out there and it's very hard when a market doesn't exist to size it, but you can already see startups out there that trying to serve some of the markets as well as some of the other incumbents. And in total, there's proba
componenttext: Yes, I mean, what you can look at out there and it's very hard when a market doesn't exist to size it, but you can already see startups out there that trying to serve some of the markets as well as some of the other incumbents. And in total, there's probably a couple hundred million dollars already being sold in the area of collaboration and coordination software. I think that market is going to grow tremendously. And that's what's available to us. There's really critical that we get out the BIM 360 docs like you said. We had incredible success with our enterprise, Architecture, Engineering and Construction customers, but they were missing out on smaller parts of the market, and that's really gets the scale. But I mean, these are opportunities that certainly in the hundreds of thousands of potential users, and in some cases, possibly in millions. But if you want to just look more specifically, for example, many of the people on the construction side will use BIM 360 were not a user of our designer engineering products. If you look at PLM 360, it drives the use of our manufacturing products throughout the whole enterprise as opposed to just people that are design and engineering. So it's a very different use profile. It's also why you said just some of the other comments, when you look at some of these cost subscriptions, when you include these will be lower priced products. And that's what kind of dampens the growth. So just trying to tie them together but things are really no uses of that haven't been available, whereas before I talked about there's 3 pools of users and use of the desktop for the new cloud-based design products.

componenttext: One thought is that I would assume that geography is the but I go into the model transition, which show the steepest revenue decline. Just trying to get your analysis into what to make of the fact that Asia Pac decreased faster than EMEA and Americas? I mean, that would seem to suggest that if you didn't know a whole lot that, that's the reason that it's model transition but clearly that historically not been the case with model transitions. So trying to get your view on that. And also from a product perspective it would seem that is going through the sharpest decline there for the model transition is more prevalent there. But again, that would not make sense. So I'm trying to get some sense in your perspective as to what to make of the disparity in the growth rates of this geography and product types.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, right, Cash. I think you're thinking about it in the right way, but let me put a little bit of a different distraction on it. The places where the year-on-year growth is less impacted by the model transition are the places where they were earlier t
componenttext: Right, right, Cash. I think you're thinking about it in the right way, but let me put a little bit of a different distraction on it. The places where the year-on-year growth is less impacted by the model transition are the places where they were earlier to adopt the new model. So the compare point a year ago already had a reasonable mix or a growing mix of new model subs built into it. That was not the case in APAC, right? APAC has been the slowest was to adopt the new models so the compare point for our APAC revenues for the quarter compares back to a quarter that very had little new model mix inside theer. So it's more impacted in terms of the year-on-year growth rates. Yes, one of the encouraging signs we saw this quarter was the proportion in APAC of new model subscriptions for the Suites. So there are portions of Asia that are moving. It's not uniform, but we were very surprised and pleasantly to see such a large percentage and exceeded the other geos in terms of new model subscription. So we're seeing some traction there. Also a lot of it just so you understand it and maybe you can reconcile it, some of you are doing things like channel checks. One of the biggest factors affecting the uptake is actually the sentiment of the reseller. Resellers have a huge impact in what they present to our customers. Our best resellers are all on board with the new model some of the wins that are staying behind our influencing it. And some sometimes of that carries over into geographic distinctions. Actually big enough to be called out.

componenttext: What you're seeing there is continuation of what we've seen all along as Suites because [indiscernible] it's dominated by AutoCAD and AutoCAD LT of those product are included in the Suites. So as the Suites continue to grow and gain traction, fewer people are buying just the stand-alone versions. So a lot of what's happening in that PSEB segment is simply mix of customers getting all the CAD and getting LT but getting it inside their suite.

componenttext: Philosophically, when are we going to see the clear distinction in the product roadmap between the licenses and the desktop versions? headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think as soon as you start seeing the collections, they'll become clear. I think that will begin to have an impact in Q3. So corrections are one of the vehicles to move our customers from maintenance to product subscription. It is more valuable, it is m
componenttext: I think as soon as you start seeing the collections, they'll become clear. I think that will begin to have an impact in Q3. So corrections are one of the vehicles to move our customers from maintenance to product subscription. It is more valuable, it is more valuable. It's way more flexible than anything they've had. It gives a broader access to a wider set of products. That would be one of the tools that we use to encourage our customers to consider the new offerings.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: The sound quality wasn't great, Ken, but I think I got your question on collection. It is a case where we have, as Carl said in the opening commentary, we haven't formally rolled this out worldwide. But as we do think of it as sort of the follow-on to sui
componenttext: The sound quality wasn't great, Ken, but I think I got your question on collection. It is a case where we have, as Carl said in the opening commentary, we haven't formally rolled this out worldwide. But as we do think of it as sort of the follow-on to suite as the next generation of what Suites look like. It will be greatly simplified -- the pricing model will be greatly simplified. It will bring along with it substantial addition of value in terms of the number of products that are included. It also will begin to form the on ramp from desktop execution software to cloud software, will incorporate a lot of our club property that to make it something that's not a separate buying decision to go out and have our customers test out and try out the cloud products. So we at it as not just the next step in adding value and driving with customers to see the higher value of the new subscription models but also as an on-ramp to the cloud.

componenttext: Let me just add one thing to that. [indiscernible] The other thing I'd add because we've been slightly about this is one of the other things to remember is our ability to consolidate the product portfolio, shrink the product portfolio. This is the first step towards doing this. So people have asked about the product portfolio. Collections are the vehicle that allowed us to simplify the product portfolio, focus on the important ones, trim the parts that make less sense and much more disciplined around the R&D expense. And so we're really excited about concentrating the offerings for the different industries. We're the only with these 3 collections.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is John Byun for Brent Thill. So just 2 questions. One, with the Q2 revenue outlook being a little bit lower than consensus, I mean -- but the year the same, should we think of that -- would it be [indiscernible] mismodeling the seasonality? Or was t
componenttext: This is John Byun for Brent Thill. So just 2 questions. One, with the Q2 revenue outlook being a little bit lower than consensus, I mean -- but the year the same, should we think of that -- would it be [indiscernible] mismodeling the seasonality? Or was there any change in your expected path or as you go through the end of perpetual on Suites through the rest of the year? What will be the best way to think about that?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I recognize that the guide we gave for the quarter is not where consensus was, but of course, we haven't guided Q2 before. And what we're seeing in our guidance [indiscernible]. what our expectations were. So it's not a question of a change in seasonality
componenttext: I recognize that the guide we gave for the quarter is not where consensus was, but of course, we haven't guided Q2 before. And what we're seeing in our guidance [indiscernible]. what our expectations were. So it's not a question of a change in seasonality pattern versus what had been expected previously. If you just look at -- come into the end of sale of Suites during Q2, we talked about earlier we are expecting really a bit of limited buy-ahead versus what we saw on individual products. On the stand-alone products remember we size it at the end of Q4, there was only about a 10% increase in volume that came through. Suites, to begin with, are a much lower volume product stand-alone products are. We're also seeing and have seen a really steady increase in the uptake of customers already buying the new model on Suites. So not waiting for it to hit end of sale. There's been a lot of interest in suite customers buying the new model. So you add those 2 together, we're expecting a small amount of buy-ahead activity in Q2 on Suites but not a huge amount. It's bigger than we think will be toward the high end of the range. And if it's less than we think, which is would be a good thing because customers don't have to convert perpetual in the future the question we think that will be low end of the range.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. One of the things I would just outline 2 things about it. One is just generally, we're seeing greater support amongst customers and our partners in the new model, so that is running ahead of plan. But it was interesting, like I said, I was yesterday
componenttext: Yes. One of the things I would just outline 2 things about it. One is just generally, we're seeing greater support amongst customers and our partners in the new model, so that is running ahead of plan. But it was interesting, like I said, I was yesterday with our largest North American resellers or many of our largest North American resellers and just going around the room. There was a good betting going on about how much buy-ahead there would be of Suites at the end of the quarter. As we said, the best we can say about this is we've never experienced this before. It's different and this is really just our best estimate of what's going to go on. The more important news for us is that whatever happens, we're done with it at the end of this quarter. And so whether it's the low end of the range or we're happy are the high end of the range it doesn't matter because we move on to a world that we've been waiting for. I'm talking about for a while, in which we're just really selling only the new model. [indiscernible] simplify so much stuff, so I will be thrilled when we're here 3 months from now.
