headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Autodesk Second Quarter Fiscal 2017 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to hand the conference over to David Gennarelli,
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Autodesk Second Quarter Fiscal 2017 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. 
I would now like to hand the conference over to David Gennarelli, Senior Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, operator. Good afternoon. Thank you for joining our conference call to discuss the results of our second quarter of fiscal 2017. Also on the line is Carl Bass, our CEO; and Scott Herren, our CFO. Today's call is being broadcast live via webcast. I
componenttext:
Thanks, operator. Good afternoon. Thank you for joining our conference call to discuss the results of our second quarter of fiscal 2017. Also on the line is Carl Bass, our CEO; and Scott Herren, our CFO. Today's call is being broadcast live via webcast. In addition, a replay of the call will be available at autodesk.com/investor. 
As noted in our press release, we have published our prepared remarks and our website in advance of this call. Those remarks are intended to serve in place of extended formal comments, and we will not repeat them on this call. 
During the course of this conference call, we will make forward-looking statements regarding future events and anticipated future performance of the company such as our guidance for the third quarter and full year fiscal 2017; our long-term financial model guidance; the factors we use to estimate our guidance, including currency headwinds; expectations regarding our restructuring; our transition to new business models; our market opportunities and strategies and trends for various products, geographies and industries. We caution you that such statements reflect our best judgment based on factors currently known to us and that actual events or results to differ materially. Please refer to the documents we file from time to time with the SEC, specifically our Form 10-K for the fiscal year 2016, our Form 10-Q for the period ending April 30, 2016, and our current reports on Form 8-K, including the Form 8-K furnished with today's press release and in prepared remarks. Those documents contain and identify important risks and other factors that may cause our actual results to differ from those contained in our forward-looking statements. 
Forward-looking statements made during the call are being made as of today. If this call is replayed or reviewed after today, the information presented during the call may not contain current or accurate information. Autodesk disclaims any obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements. We will provide guidance on today's call, but will not provide any further guidance or updates on our performance during the quarter unless we do so in a public forum. 
During the call, we will also discuss non-GAAP financial measures. Those non-GAAP financial measures are not prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles. A reconciliation of our GAAP and non-GAAP results is provided in today's press release, prepared remarks and on the Investor Relations section of our website. We will quote a number of numeric or growth changes as we discuss our financial performance, and unless otherwise noted, each such reference represents a year-on-year comparison. 
And now, I'd like to turn the call over to Carl.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave. We had a terrific quarter, and we reached a very important milestone with the end of selling perpetual licenses. Our Q2 results mark another solid quarter of execution and progress on our 2 big initiatives: Increasing lifetime customer value
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave. We had a terrific quarter, and we reached a very important milestone with the end of selling perpetual licenses. Our Q2 results mark another solid quarter of execution and progress on our 2 big initiatives: Increasing lifetime customer value; and secondly, driving increased adoption of our cloud-based solutions. I'll share more details on our Q2 results and then update you on what we've been doing around creating long-term shareholder value before getting into the current quarter and our outlook for the rest of the year. 
Starting with subscription numbers, we added 109,000 net use subscriptions in the quarter. We're really happy with the growth that new model subscription additions, which more than doubled year-over-year to 125,000. It was a strong quarter for product subscriptions, which drove the vast majority of the new model sub additions and is the clearest sign of the progress on the transition with our customers and partners. Keep in mind that we didn't have any big promotions going on like we did in Q1. 
Product subscriptions had strong sequential growth and dramatic year-over-year growth of over 3x. Product subscriptions come to us from a number of sources. We're really pleased to see that one of the primary sources continues to be net new customers, which accounted for approximately 1/3 of product subscription additions in Q2. It's impossible to get perfect clarity on these new customers, but it's likely that a portion of these people were previously pirating software and now have a much more affordable option with our subscriptions. Still others have been using alternative design tool and can now get access to better software. 
Looking at the other new model subscription types. Our token-based EBAs experienced good year-over-year growth, but added fewer than we did in our seasonally high Q1. And once again, we had a record quarter for cloud subscription additions. BIM 360 and Fusion 360 are leading the way, and we continue to have success with our other cloud products such as Shotgun and Fusion life cycle, formerly known as PLM 360. We continue to build on our leadership in the cloud and our cloud services play an increasingly important role in our transition. 
Maintenance is our other primary subscription bucket. The renewal rate for maintenance subscriptions increase significantly year-over-year and remain near historic highs. Keep in mind as we go forward, we'll start to experience larger decreases in maintenance subscriptions since we are no longer selling perpetual licenses. We will also be incentivizing customers on maintenance to switch to a product subscription. As we've outlined in the past, by the end of next fiscal year, we expect to have more customers in our new model subscriptions than maintenance subscriptions. We are adamant about supporting our maintenance customers, and at some point in the future, these programs will converge into a single subscription offering. 
As we've indicated before, growth in subscriptions will drive growth in ARR. The strong growth in new model subscriptions in Q2 fueled an 86% year-on-year constant currency increase in new model ARR. Total ARR was -- growth was 14% in constant currency year-over-year. Total recurring revenue was 67% of our total reported revenues. That's a big jump compared to 55% in Q2 last year and a slight decrease from last quarter due to the surge in perpetual Suites sales. With just a few exceptions, we're now in a subscription-only model, so you can expect another jump in the percentage of recurring revenue, starting in Q3. 
Our Q2 revenue results were well ahead of expectations, and were influenced primarily by a larger-than-expected surge in last opportunity buying of perpetual licenses for Suites. Recall that in Q4, we added 10% increase in unit volume related to the end of sale of perpetual licenses for individual products. Our analysis of Q2 suggest that just under 20% of our unit volume was related to end-of-sale activities for Suites. This was bigger than expected and it like to give you some insights on what we saw. It was only over the last 2 weeks of the quarter that we started to experience a surge in demand for Suites perpetual licenses, almost entirely driven by the channel. What was really interesting is that at the same time we experienced the uptick in perpetual license sales, we also saw the acceleration of product subscriptions sales. The unique aspect of this activity relative to what we experienced in Q4 is that roughly half of the volume for Suites came from customers cross grading from an individual product. This is neutral to the subscription count since the customer has to be on maintenance in order to cross grade, but it's absolutely positive for in-period revenue and, ultimately, ARR, since the will be paying more annually for their maintenance plan. Overall, the increase in volume related to the end of perpetual Suites was greater than we anticipated, but we are very pleased with how product subscriptions performed in the quarter and the overall net result as positive for Autodesk. 
Our total unit volume in the second quarter increase compared to Q2 last year and was in line with our expectations even when normalizing for the increased activity related to the end of sale for Suites. It's not surprising that the end of sale for Suites drove a sequential uptick in license revenue. What might be surprising if that we're not seeing faster growth in our as-reported subscription revenue line. 
There are 2 things that are inhibiting that growth. The first is FX, which is causing about a 4-point headwind. The second is the accounting treatment of product subscriptions and EBA revenue. While our new model subscriptions are deferred and recognized ratably over their contract length, a sizable portion of both our product subscription and our EBAs are recognized as license revenue. In fact, roughly 80% of product subscription and roughly 55% of EBAs get recorded as license revenue. Cloud is the only new model subscription type that gets 100% recorded as obstruction revenue. If all the new model subscriptions were recognized 100% as subscription revenue, that line would show 10% year-over-year growth as reported and 14% growth adjusted for currency. We are currently working towards providing a clearer breakout of our reporting so that our total as subscription revenue can be seen directly in our reporting disclosures. 
Now let me get into a few more details of our Q2 results. By now, it should be very clear that our channel partners are fully engaged with our subscription model. 68% of new model subscription additions came through our channel partners compared to just 47% in Q2 last year and 63% last quarter. The volume of subscriptions coming through our eStore also continued to gain momentum and nearly doubled from Q2 last year. Total direct revenue was 25% in the second quarter despite most of the search from the end of sale of Suites coming through the channel. That's up from 2% in Q2 last year. 
On the expense side. Our total spend decreased by almost 4% as we continue to diligently control our spending. We are continuing to make structural changes that allow us to spend less yet focus on our key initiatives. While we are being very disciplined about our spending, we are doing it without compromising the long-term health of the company. We also increased our stock buyback in Q2 to $170 million, in light of the dip in the stock caused by a temporary panic around the Brexit vote. 
Overall, we were very pleased with the Q2 results. All of the trends we sawed reinforce our confidence that the transition is working for our customers, our partners and Autodesk. That's a good segue way into what I've touched on in the last couple of earnings calls about what we're doing to create long-term value for our shareholders. We continue to get many questions in this area so I'm happy to talk about it. If you've been around the tech industry as long as I have, you've no doubt seen the carnage of once great technology companies that ultimately failed to innovate and keep their competitive advantage. Autodesk has been the leader in the world of design and engineering software for over 30 years and what we're doing with this transition is positioning Autodesk to lead the next generation of this kind of software. Our transition happens on 2 fronts. We are currently in the midst of a business model and pricing transition, where our customers are moving to term-based subscriptions. This will lead to a highly predictable model over time and a significant increase in the value our customers get from our products. The best indicator for this is the rapid growth we're experiencing in new model subscriptions and new model ARR. In support of this model change, we are simplifying our entire go-to-market strategy and reducing our cost structure while we increase our ability to more effectively serve our customers. 
The second front of our transition is how we are building platforms to exploit the cloud and dramatically expand the size of our market opportunities. We're well ahead of our traditional competitors on this front, and we're investing to secure the future of Autodesk. These mobile and cloud technologies are opening up significant opportunities in the areas of construction and Manufacturing that are completely new to Autodesk. These new platforms are for once-in-a-generation opportunity to redefine the competitive landscape. Our cloud-based products continue to gain momentum and are already the undisputed leaders in their respective categories. 
So this is how I'd summarize how we're building long-term shareholder value with 3 simple bullets: one, we are increasing the lifetime value of every customer; two, we're changing our cost structure by focusing our product portfolio and go-to-market strategies; and three, we're building the best cloud and mobile-based products and services in the industry, which significantly expands our total available market as the underlying technology platform shifts to the cloud. 
Now let's take a look at what's going on here in the current quarter, Q3. Our newly introduced Collections are a great example of increasing lifetime customer value. On August 1, we launched Collections, which is our next generation of Suites with the addition of our cloud services. Suites was tremendously successful for Autodesk, but with Collections, we're significantly reducing complexity by offering just 3 Collections, one for AEC, one for Manufacturing and one for M&E, making them easier to sell and consume. We're offering single-user and multiuser access and choices of different term lengths to fit their needs. The value of our customers is tremendous and well exceeds the premium suite. We priced Collections so that the average customer value to Autodesk will increase as well. We're only 25 days into selling Collections, but we're very happy with the start. 
Despite the strong performance of Suites at the end of Q2, in the first few weeks, we received the same volume levels for Collections that we experienced for Suites in the same period a year ago. From a tactical standpoint, some of you have been asking about pricing and promotions. We are currently running another promotion aimed at our legacy customers. It's similar to the very successful promotion that we ran in Q1, but the discount are smaller. You can expect us to continue to work to convert these legacy customers with the various promotions and incentives as we go forward. Like I've said before, running a business in different than running a spreadsheet. One area that we constantly evaluate is how we use pricing to drive subscriptions and ARR growth. Having said that, we wouldn't make significant decisions around packaging for pricing without first testing in certain markets. This is especially true when it comes to our flagship products like AutoCAD and guilty. 
In early September, pricing changes will go into effect that will rationalize the pricing of AutoCAD LT, AutoCAD and the AutoCAD verticals. We believe these moves will drive customers to the right products for their needs and higher billings and ARR for Autodesk. 
Now turning to our outlook for Q3 and the full year. Our review of the macroeconomic environment's impact on our business hasn't changed over the past several quarters. The global conditions have remained uneven with most of the mature markets performing relatively well, while most of the emerging markets have been challenged. As we evaluated our strong Q2 results, we didn't see any meaningful change in the demand environment. And as I indicated earlier, we don't see any immediate fallout from the Brexit vote. As always, it's impossible to say what the long-term impact might be, but we don't see any near-term risk. Our strong Q2 results likely pulled forward some demand from the second half of the year, but we're comfortable with bringing up the bottom end of our previous ranges for both revenue and EPS for FY '17. We're also lowering our spend projection for FY '17 based on the better-than-expected progress we've made on this front. We remain confident in our long-term goals of growing our subscription base by 20% CAGR through FY '20, which will drive a 24% CAGR in ARR. We also remain committed to keeping spend growth flat in FY '18. The lower spend projection also enhances our projected path to free cash flow off roughly $6 per share in FY '20 and $11 per share in FY '23. 
So to wrap things up, we're very pleased with the consistent execution over the past few quarters. We're really excited to be another major step further along in the transition and now fully in the subscription-only model. We have a clear vision and plan for creating a more predictable, recurring and profitable business in the years to come. We are focused on driving higher lifetime value, simplifying our offerings and our go-to-market activities and significantly increasing our market opportunities as we lead the next wave of design and engineering software to the cloud. 
Operator, we'd now like to open the call up for questions.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Jay Vleeschhouwer from Griffin Securities.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Jay Vleeschhouwer from Griffin Securities.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Carl, let me ask you first about the pricing that you plan to take next month. Could you give some specifics as to how you're thinking about what the changes might be? And is this part of what you referred to in the past as SRP realization as a concept fo
componenttext: Carl, let me ask you first about the pricing that you plan to take next month. Could you give some specifics as to how you're thinking about what the changes might be? And is this part of what you referred to in the past as SRP realization as a concept for you to help improve pricing and margin? Secondly, with respect to the decay of classic maintenance over time, how are you thinking about the rate of that decline? When we look at one of your competitors, I think, you see which is moving mostly but not entirely to subscription, the state of rate of decline for their maintenance is low to mid-single digits. So would you anticipate going fully to [indiscernible] subscription that your decay of maintenance might be so much faster than that?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So let me start with the pricing and then Scott and I can kind of tag team one about the maintenance decline. So starting to the pricing. What we wanted to do was, as I said, kind of rationalize the 3 different price points of AutoCAD LT, AutoCAD and
componenttext: Yes. So let me start with the pricing and then Scott and I can kind of tag team one about the maintenance decline. So starting to the pricing. What we wanted to do was, as I said, kind of rationalize the 3 different price points of AutoCAD LT, AutoCAD and the AutoCAD verticals. Whenever possible, we would like customers to get the right product. More often than not, that is on AutoCAD verticals, particularly tailored to what the discipline they're in. And on the other side, for the more casual users, LT is clearly the more appropriate product. And what we were trying to do is move the price points apart, get the appropriate separations. And what we saw and a kind of referred to in the remarks, in our testing is that we can with the right pricing, move more healthy customers to AutoCAD and AutoCAD customers to the verticals. And so this is a part of the overall pricing, I wouldn't say it's particularly what I would refer to as ARPU realization. It's just increasing total pricing, but it's part of pricing optimization strategy. And let me take the first pass. A couple of things will contribute to the maintenance decline, as you said, classic maintenance. One is going to be the of from people who just choose not to renew for all of the usual reasons. The second one would be the conversion of the maintenance customers on to the subscription side. And on the first  one, we talked a little bit about it in that we said that we expected the subscription base to be larger by the end of next year. We gave you some hints or at least we gave you [indiscernible] trouble you can work on tonight, Jay. And then on the second one, we also talked a little bit about programmatic ways of doing that over time, highly will continue to encourage customers to move from classic maintenance to the new subscriptions. Scott, do you want to add something?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think you said it right. The decay rate. We feel very, within that pool of maintenance subscribers by the way between low-end LT customers that have a slightly lower renewal rate versus Suites maintenance customers, which have a much higher renewal
componenttext: No, I think you said it right. The decay rate. We feel very, within that pool of maintenance subscribers by the way between low-end LT customers that have a slightly lower renewal rate versus Suites maintenance customers, which have a much higher renewal rate. So as that pull moves over, the maintenance pull will go continually down from this point, basically 1 minus per turn rate. And at that point, what you'll see is the mix will shift inside that pool. So if you think of maintenance revenue as a key time SKU, think of the prize, the average price inside there beginning to shift more toward Suites customers out through time. But the overall decline will be driven by the lower LT customers. I think the other way to peg this, Jay, as you sit down into your modeling, is what we said, I think we should do these things back at Investor Day, that our expectation is by the end of next year, the number of maintenance subscribers and the maintenance ARR will be below the new model subscribers and to model ARR by the end of next year.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Saket Kalia from Barclays.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Saket Kalia from Barclays.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe first to start off, I know ARR, maybe this is to you, Scott but and I know ARR is a better metric to look at. But for those of us who still look at billings, can you just give us a sense for how billings are maybe trending for those new model subscr
componenttext: Maybe first to start off, I know ARR, maybe this is to you, Scott but and I know ARR is a better metric to look at. But for those of us who still look at billings, can you just give us a sense for how billings are maybe trending for those new model subscribers or new model billings versus maintenance billings? Because you obviously have a headwind from evidence in that different revenue accounts, so any color on how new model billings are doing would be helpful.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Saket. One of the reasons that I don't think millions of the best indicator of our progress is, of course, they're term specific. And if I sign a new customer, but they only sign up for 1 year, that's a third of the billings [indiscernible] the time
componenttext: Yes, Saket. One of the reasons that I don't think millions of the best indicator of our progress is, of course, they're term specific. And if I sign a new customer, but they only sign up for 1 year, that's a third of the billings [indiscernible] the time that same customer, 3 years. So I think, it's a little bit less of an indicator than things like ARR, which are annualized and, of course, the overall subscription growth. But if you do the quick math, deferred revenue change by $3 million during the quarter, so our billings track pretty much to our reported revenues. And when you peel back billings at a high level, they track very much in line with what you see in subscription versus license.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, that's helpful. And then my follow-up, Carl, I think, you mentioned that you saw good crossgrade activity for maintenance and product subscriptions, which, of course, is a net neutral to the subs count. Can you just give us a sense for how many of
componenttext: Got it, that's helpful. And then my follow-up, Carl, I think, you mentioned that you saw good crossgrade activity for maintenance and product subscriptions, which, of course, is a net neutral to the subs count. Can you just give us a sense for how many of those crossgrades you saw this quarter? And then more broadly, are you still seeing customers from product versions older than 5 years to make that crossgrade?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so let me go backwards. So we didn't see customers from very far back because we didn't run into any of the promotion. So the typical kind of legacy promotion where people had to be on subsection already. What I did mention is that in Q3, we were run
componenttext: Yes, so let me go backwards. So we didn't see customers from very far back because we didn't run into any of the promotion. So the typical kind of legacy promotion where people had to be on subsection already. What I did mention is that in Q3, we were running a similar promotion to the one that we ran in Q1, so again, we'll talk about that 90 days from now see and how many of the legacy customers we can attract. We didn't break out the number on your other question of people who converted, but it was a substantial number. I'll leave it as Scott if he want to give a number.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The color, I'd add to that, is if you think of the quarter that we just closed, we actually saw 2 end-of-sale surges kind of at the same time. There was -- the normal end-of-sale surge that like we saw in Q4, where it was the last chance for our cust
componenttext: Yes. The color, I'd add to that, is if you think of the quarter that we just closed, we actually saw 2 end-of-sale surges kind of at the same time. There was -- the normal end-of-sale surge that like we saw in Q4, where it was the last chance for our customer who wanted to buy a Suite perpetual license and there are some buy ahead activity, some pull ahead of future demand for that set of customers. And by the way, we predicted that, I think, pretty accurately versus what the results were. The piece that also happens, of course, when we saw our last perpetual license, you also saw your last crossgrade. And we saw a lot of the same behavior that we saw at the end -- if you remember when we stop selling upgrades in our fiscal '15, so more than a year ago, we saw a big spike in demand for people who were already using our product, but decided they wanted to upgrade to a more full function product. They're willing to pay more for it. We saw some of that same upgrade-like behavior happened within our crossgrade. And I think, that's the piece that surprised us a bit and it's a positive for ARR. It's a neutral for subscribers because you had to be on maintenance to be eligible for the cross grade, but it's a positive for ARR and is a positive for total revenue going forward. So that's of the way I would think about the surge we saw at the end of this quarter.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Richard Davis from Canaccord.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Richard Davis from Canaccord.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it sounds like -- I mean, you're getting good growth as you kind of pointing out, reduced piracy and also kind of changed vendors. The question that I hear, when you hear from people thinking about changing vendors as a big hurdle is just kind of the d
componenttext: So it sounds like -- I mean, you're getting good growth as you kind of pointing out, reduced piracy and also kind of changed vendors. The question that I hear, when you hear from people thinking about changing vendors as a big hurdle is just kind of the data migration and things like that. Has there been any -- have you guys done anything technologically to make that less painful? Because if I have a model set in a different vendor, I'm terrified that if I moved over to you guys, it will incinerate me or something like that. That's really kind of -- help me understand how you can make that less fearful for these folks trying to...

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Despite this advice of our legal counsel, I can guarantee you, it will not incinerate you, Richard. Let me just divide the markets and talk about the dynamics slightly differently. In the ASC market, which is more product based, it comes up for a bui
componenttext: Yes. Despite this advice of our legal counsel, I can guarantee you, it will not incinerate you, Richard. Let me just divide the markets and talk about the dynamics slightly differently. In the ASC market, which is more product based, it comes up for a building or roadway or a bridge. There is more willingness -- there's slightly more willingness to shift with new projects as new teams come together. I think, the place where you hear even greater reluctance is in Manufacturing. And there, we did -- we've done a number of things that we've rolled out across our product portfolio that allow customers to work in new software and access the data that they created over the last couple of decades. So they can work with the native data, they don't -- obviously, as always, we can translate it and convert it, But even more importantly, we now let customers leave their data in a data format and work on it whether they're doing modeling or visualization or simulations. So that is over the last 2 years, a pretty big breakthroughs in giving people a much smoother ramp to go from one of the legacy products to a new one. And at a certain point, one of the other things that has to happen in motivating people to move to something is the new stuff has to be that much better. If you think about it, particularly Manufacturing, many of the products that people are using are more than 20 years old. And we would like to think in the industry that we can do better than having 20-year-old products be state of the art. So part of it is making the new products and the new product experiences much more compelling. The other is to reassure people about being able to migrate their data or to use all their data and access it for as long as they need to.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Heather Bellini from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Heather Bellini from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is [indiscernible] for Heather. First one is on expenses. So your expenses were down 4% this quarter and you've already guided for the year. Can you talk about some of the actions you've taken that are driving this spend to be lower than you're expec
componenttext: This is [indiscernible] for Heather. First one is on expenses. So your expenses were down 4% this quarter and you've already guided for the year. Can you talk about some of the actions you've taken that are driving this spend to be lower than you're expected? In the past, you talked about discontinuing some noncore products in trade of hardware. So I'm wondering if we can see more of that? Are you done with that type of product streamlining?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The 2 biggest places have clearly been on consolidation of the product portfolio, and the second place is I'll just and say overall in our go-to-market activities. As it refers to the product portfolio, I mean, we are on a multiyear transition to a much m
componenttext: The 2 biggest places have clearly been on consolidation of the product portfolio, and the second place is I'll just and say overall in our go-to-market activities. As it refers to the product portfolio, I mean, we are on a multiyear transition to a much more streamlined portfolio, including making the end of life of certain products. But also, as you look at Collections as a big certification from Suites, all across the board, we are trying to signify the portfolio, making it easy for our customers, make it easy and our partners. And so we'll continue to see the folding in of certain functionality into the products that we keep going forward, the elimination of some of the older and less important ones. And we're constantly pruning for the things that work and don't work. So I would not at all expect to see -- or said more positively, I'd expect to see that same kind of proactive management of the portfolio for the next couple of years.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, that's helpful. And for my follow-up, new model subs, the additions of 1 25 is higher than we're expecting. Can you just give some more color on the mix that was traditional desktop and EBA versus new cloud offerings? And are we starting to  see n
componenttext: Got it, that's helpful. And for my follow-up, new model subs, the additions of 1 25 is higher than we're expecting. Can you just give some more color on the mix that was traditional desktop and EBA versus new cloud offerings? And are we starting to  see new cloud subs become a higher portion of the ads now?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Shateel. This is Scott here. We had a record, I think, Carl mentioned this actually in the opening cpmmentary. We had a record quarter for cloud sub ads, so it continues to move along nicely. But that new model space will continue to do this quarter
componenttext: Yes, Shateel. This is Scott here. We had a record, I think, Carl mentioned this actually in the opening cpmmentary. We had a record quarter for cloud sub ads, so it continues to move along nicely. But that new model space will continue to do this quarter and will continue into the future to be dominated by product subscriptions, so term licenses. In fact, for the first time, we had more inventory of product subscriptions within the new model type than in the enterprise coming out of the EBAs. So think of it as being dominated by product subscriptions, EBAs would be next, cloud would be next.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Gregg Moskowitz from Cowen & Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Gregg Moskowitz from Cowen & Company.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Carl, if you look at Asia-Pac, customers there had historically moved more slowly to adopt your subscriptions. In the Q1, however, you did reference, I think, an uptick in new model subscriptions towards the end of that period. Can you give us an update o
componenttext: Carl, if you look at Asia-Pac, customers there had historically moved more slowly to adopt your subscriptions. In the Q1, however, you did reference, I think, an uptick in new model subscriptions towards the end of that period. Can you give us an update on what you saw out of Asia in Q2?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I will continue to say that parts of Asia a slower to adopt the new model. We had some pockets of success with some of our traditional partners in some of the electronic channels that have been more positive, but overall, slightly slower adop
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I will continue to say that parts of Asia a slower to adopt the new model. We had some pockets of success with some of our traditional partners in some of the electronic channels that have been more positive, but overall, slightly slower adoption with a handful of countries. And as you do the analysis, it's a little bit hard to dissect exactly what's going on since up until now, the preference of the channel partners kind of shown through that they were able to exert third and fourth on the customers. Moving forward, that goes away so, hopefully, everyone will be aligned. It's a great relief to make it to August 1st and get into just in the new model. And I suspect going forward, we'll see more normalization. But given that there were 2 choices, Asia-Pac certainly lagged a little bit.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then just for Scott, based on where you are at this point in the year, you're calling for about 250,000 or so net subscribers in the second half, at least at the midpoint of the range. And I know you don't guide quarterly, of cou
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then just for Scott, based on where you are at this point in the year, you're calling for about 250,000 or so net subscribers in the second half, at least at the midpoint of the range. And I know you don't guide quarterly, of course, but maybe you could just share with the group your high-level thoughts around net adds for Q3 as compared with Q4 as you see it today.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure, Greg. We always have a seasonal pattern of demand. If you think of where the subs will come into the second half of the year, there will be more than 100% of what we had will be new model, right, maintenance will on a continual flow, but on a s
componenttext: Yes, sure, Greg. We always have a seasonal pattern of demand. If you think of where the subs will come into the second half of the year, there will be more than 100% of what we had will be new model, right, maintenance will on a continual flow, but on a steady decline. So all of the new ads will come from new model types. New model types tend to have the seasonality of a lot of our previously our perpetual license today. So heavier in Q4 than in Q3 would be normal demand patterns. We also see Q4 typically heavy on EBA sales, although as you see in the last couple of years, there's a lot of them in Q4, the EBAs will pick up those subs in Q1. So think of this as being driven -- the Q3 versus Q4 driven by normal seasonality pattern first. And then secondarily, we do think there were some demand pulled forward from some of the end of sale of Suites at the very end of Q2 that probably makes Q3 from a sub adds standpoint a little bit more challenging but, what we'd normally expect and with normal seasonality.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Ken Wong from Citigroup.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Ken Wong from Citigroup.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question for you, Carl, with Collections know that's been out in the market for about a month, how should we think about kind of the customers you're attracting here? Is it customers that are using a few products moving up to Collections? Or are
componenttext: My first question for you, Carl, with Collections know that's been out in the market for about a month, how should we think about kind of the customers you're attracting here? Is it customers that are using a few products moving up to Collections? Or are you seeing your traditional suite customers kind of recognizing incremental value with this conference is a bundle and those are ones that are primarily moving toward the Collections?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ken, it's just probably a little early to know for sure. And it's almost like give us 2 more months and this first month, we have certainly seen some of the Suites customers move over. Some of the buying at the end of the quarter was anticipation of
componenttext: Yes, Ken, it's just probably a little early to know for sure. And it's almost like give us 2 more months and this first month, we have certainly seen some of the Suites customers move over. Some of the buying at the end of the quarter was anticipation of being able to move from Suites to Collections. So there's certainly some of that in there, but we'll be able to do a little bit better breakdown of the customers when we get a little bit more traction there. It's just a little bit premature.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then earlier in your prepared remarks, you mentioned at some point convert to a single subscription offering. Is this just consistent with what you guys have done in the past, where it's just kind of a natural bleed off of maintenance and then
componenttext: Got it. And then earlier in your prepared remarks, you mentioned at some point convert to a single subscription offering. Is this just consistent with what you guys have done in the past, where it's just kind of a natural bleed off of maintenance and then you'll eventually just be all kind of new model subs? Or is there something more specific that you guys are looking to do to try to converge that process sooner?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two things.  I think we're being more direct in a general sense, but it's probably at this point, we don't want to get more details. But what we do know and we have talked about the complexity and the expense that comes with multiple models. And so we'll
componenttext: Two things.  I think we're being more direct in a general sense, but it's probably at this point, we don't want to get more details. But what we do know and we have talked about the complexity and the expense that comes with multiple models. And so we'll continue to look at ways to just simplify all of the offerings and a March the programs into one is it makes sense. But I think we were descending at more proactive behavior in our part.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes,  the only color I will add to that is you've seen us do some of this already. First with Suites and now with Collections, you see us bundling together to kind of ease and the ramp from -- you see us bundling the Windows-based, whether it's perpetual
componenttext: Yes,  the only color I will add to that is you've seen us do some of this already. First with Suites and now with Collections, you see us bundling together to kind of ease and the ramp from -- you see us bundling the Windows-based, whether it's perpetual license or product subscriptions, with cloud to kind of ease that on a ramp. And I think you'll see us continue to do more of that to make it easier to consume, to give customers a choice within what they bought to execute whichever product that they like. That was one of the guiding guidance with the way we define Collections and I think you'll just see that continue.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016

componenttext: Most of my questions have been asked, but let me ask about Japan. Just maybe color on what is going on there? And is there, trend wise, any hope or any color on that will be great.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say flatline. It is what it is. It hasn't gotten better and it hasn't gotten worse. Scott, when you want to...
componenttext: I'd say flatline. It is what it is. It hasn't gotten better and it hasn't gotten worse. Scott, when you want to...

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, that's right. I think, the year-on-year impact on Japan and probably more pronounced than elsewhere because they were slower last year to adopt a new model type so the falling off a cliff of going from perpetual license the new model type this mo
componenttext: I think, that's right. I think, the year-on-year impact on Japan and probably more pronounced than elsewhere because they were slower last year to adopt a new model type so the falling off a cliff of going from perpetual license the new model type this more pronounced in Japan that it is elsewhere. I think that's part of what we're seeing. Part of it is just the continuation of the trend that we see where it's been a tough economy in Japan and we feel some of that.  And I think there's no change is what I'd say, Steve. But I think part of what we're feeling from a year-on-year standpoint is just the difference in the adoption model.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of the promotions you're running, you've been great about calling out the fact that you are running a fairly aggressive promotion less discounting than we saw in the first quarter. But in terms of digital marketing and how much wood you'
componenttext: And then in terms of the promotions you're running, you've been great about calling out the fact that you are running a fairly aggressive promotion less discounting than we saw in the first quarter. But in terms of digital marketing and how much wood you're putting behind the euro, is there any difference in how visible and you will be with this promotion versus the one you ran in the first quarter?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Steve. What I said last time, we thought the promotion was generous, but not well known by all of our customers. And after having run in that 1 quarter, we thought we can turn the 2 knobs and turn down the discounting and turn up the awareness. And a
componenttext: Yes, Steve. What I said last time, we thought the promotion was generous, but not well known by all of our customers. And after having run in that 1 quarter, we thought we can turn the 2 knobs and turn down the discounting and turn up the awareness. And as we said a quarter ago, we were extremely pleased and surprised by the results and how far back into a legacy user base we could reach. And that was with, I'd say minimal awareness. And so we would like to promote that more heavily going forward and we thought we could accomplish both goals of greater SRP realization and a good response by just turning up the awareness. So you should see a little bit more of it. And as we indicated in the opening commentary, you can see more of it going forward.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Keith Weiss from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Keith Weiss from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Given the fact that Suites were a bigger part of [indiscernible] was going on in this quarter, you talked a lot about a lot more new model subscription type coming from Suites. I would've expected the ARPS number, the pricing side of the equation efficien
componenttext: Given the fact that Suites were a bigger part of [indiscernible] was going on in this quarter, you talked a lot about a lot more new model subscription type coming from Suites. I would've expected the ARPS number, the pricing side of the equation efficiency start to improve. But by my mats, it's still down sequentially little bit with the continued model subs. One -- it's a 2-part question. One, why does that continue to decline? And two, when should we expect that to turn back up and start seeing the drivers of ARR growth?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Keith. We talked about that I think last quarter as well. Part of what's going on there is just the math. When you do the ARPS calculation, you do a quarter average ARR and dividing it by a quarter and some got, right? If you go back and say quarter
componenttext: Yes, Keith. We talked about that I think last quarter as well. Part of what's going on there is just the math. When you do the ARPS calculation, you do a quarter average ARR and dividing it by a quarter and some got, right? If you go back and say quarter average ARR divided by quarter average sub count, you'll get a different answer on that. But I think overriding longer term you do need to expect for some period of time that to continue to come down. It will come down simply driven by mix. We talked about ARPS being very mix sensitive. It will continue to be mix sensitive. And as we get further out and layer on more quarters of selling Suites and Collections in our higher-priced products, only in the new model way, you'll begin to see that ARPS rebound. But short term, we'll continue -- that pool will be more heavily commented by the lower-priced LT auto [indiscernible] out there only as products subs [indiscernible] last 6 months. That's the way you ought to think about it. Very mix sensitive.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just to be a little bit more quantitative about it, I would look out about 3 [ph] quarters before we probably saw the [indiscernible]. And just because of how long it'll take for the demand on the Suite side of the equation or now the Collection side
componenttext: And just to be a little bit more quantitative about it, I would look out about 3 [ph] quarters before we probably saw the [indiscernible]. And just because of how long it'll take for the demand on the Suite side of the equation or now the Collection side of the equation to really ramp up and sort of normalize that mix? [indiscernible] once you end perpetual for Suites and all the new buying for those high-end products becomes new model, that should start sort of inflecting that number of words?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: You've got to the layer in multiple quarters of that ARR, Keith, before it gets -- it becomes representative of the total new model ARR as the things that have already been out there for 2 or 3 quarters selling it only in a new model way. So that's the re
componenttext: You've got to the layer in multiple quarters of that ARR, Keith, before it gets -- it becomes representative of the total new model ARR as the things that have already been out there for 2 or 3 quarters selling it only in a new model way. So that's the reason you see the lag. It starts now, but there will be a lag effect before you get that entire pool properly representing what the new sales will look like.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Brent Thill from UBS.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Brent Thill from UBS.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: One of the benefits of the shift that we're taking is we have a lot more clarity on day 1 of the quarter of what the reported revenues are going to look like. So as we look at both what we already have deferred revenue for Q3 sitting in backlog, we got ve
componenttext: One of the benefits of the shift that we're taking is we have a lot more clarity on day 1 of the quarter of what the reported revenues are going to look like. So as we look at both what we already have deferred revenue for Q3 sitting in backlog, we got very high coverage of the number that we forecast for Q3 and, obviously, a very high degree of certainty on that. As we move closer to Q4, we'll be that's a position in Q4 and we can evaluate if it makes sense to go up at that point.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just a follow-up on the ARPS question, it was down 7%. Should we continue to expect over the next couple of quarters that to be down mid-single digits? Is that kind of a good way to think of it? Or should we think on the higher end of the?
componenttext: Okay. And just a follow-up on the ARPS question, it was down 7%. Should we continue to expect over the next couple of quarters that to be down mid-single digits? Is that kind of a good way to think of it? Or should we think on the higher end of the?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me start, Carl. So think of ARPS at a minimum in the 2 line items, maintenance separate from new model. New model will have the trend that I just talked about 2 Keith in the prior question. But it will take a couple of quarters for that entire po
componenttext: Yes. Let me start, Carl. So think of ARPS at a minimum in the 2 line items, maintenance separate from new model. New model will have the trend that I just talked about 2 Keith in the prior question. But it will take a couple of quarters for that entire pool of new model ARR to be representative of the new sales that are going on. On the maintenance side, I think you'll see the ARPS there rebound a little bit quicker. We will see -- will continue to see higher renewal rates on Suites and Suites will become a bigger part of the pool faster. So it maybe a quarter out, it may be 2 quarters out, but I think you can expect to see ARPS rebound a little bit more quickly on the maintenance side and on the new models side.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would agree directionally with Scott, and I would say back to the mix, I think as with these businesses of legacy promotions and just the cloud services, that will affect the mix as well. So we'll be able to give a little bit more clarity as we go
componenttext: Yes. I would agree directionally with Scott, and I would say back to the mix, I think as with these businesses of legacy promotions and just the cloud services, that will affect the mix as well. So we'll be able to give a little bit more clarity as we go there.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Sterling Auty from JPMorgan.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Sterling Auty from JPMorgan.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Given the perpetual sales of Suites were higher than you expected in the quarter, is there a way to quantify the unit volume beyond the items you gave earlier? And specifically, what I'm looking for is, is there any chance that, that has an impact on your
componenttext: Given the perpetual sales of Suites were higher than you expected in the quarter, is there a way to quantify the unit volume beyond the items you gave earlier? And specifically, what I'm looking for is, is there any chance that, that has an impact on your full year 4 75 to 5 25 subscription addition number because of that pull forward?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I mean, one is we raised the bottom of the range, which is our indication that we don't think it has any effect. We remain confident in that comment and, I would say, increasingly confident about it. It was interesting to see, and as I tried to hi
componenttext: Yes. So I mean, one is we raised the bottom of the range, which is our indication that we don't think it has any effect. We remain confident in that comment and, I would say, increasingly confident about it. It was interesting to see, and as I tried to highlight in the remarks, as we saw a surge in the perpetual Suites, what we also saw was the new models stuff also take off in the last couple of weeks. So we saw higher -- obviously higher than anticipated volume. And I said when we get back out the extra buying of perpetuals Suites, it was the volume of activity that he would have expected for this quarter. It was -- it slightly exceeded our expectations. And then on top of that, we had -- we also had whatever pull forward. So I think you may see some shifting between quarters on the margin, but we're working -- we're comfortable with the guidance for the rest of this year and that's why we're willing to bring up the numbers.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Sterling, this is -- sorry, just on that last one, a little bit more context for you on the new model sub adds of 1 25 in the quarter. It you remember back in Q1, new model sub adds were 140,000. But buried in there were 2 things that didn't recur in
componenttext: Yes, Sterling, this is -- sorry, just on that last one, a little bit more context for you on the new model sub adds of 1 25 in the quarter. It you remember back in Q1, new model sub adds were 140,000. But buried in there were 2 things that didn't recur in Q2. One was promo. We didn't run that legacy-focused promo in Q2. We will do that again, as Carl said, in Q3. The second is we had a big catch up of the EBAs that rolled in, in Q1 and we're a little bit more than 25,000 of that 140,000 we had in Q1. If you net those 2 out, Q1 without those 2 is in the, call it, 90,000 range. That grew to 125,000 new model sub adds in Q2. So I don't -- there's certainly the pull ahead, I don't think, signals, any weakness in where we're headed of the new models side. The only thing to bear in mind is a part of the pull ahead that we saw significant part was driven by crossgrades. And to be eligible for a crossgrade, you have to already be a customer with a maintenance agreement attached. So all of those -- all of that pull ahead with this was really neutral to subs. They already have a sub and they have a sub now. So it's not a big piece of that pull ahead really doesn't affect the subs growth.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: That makes sense. And then the follow-up. Carl, the comment you said the subscriptions accelerating the same time as the perpetual. Were you suggesting that you had customers that were buying both perpetuals and subscriptions? Or do you think it was more
componenttext: That makes sense. And then the follow-up. Carl, the comment you said the subscriptions accelerating the same time as the perpetual. Were you suggesting that you had customers that were buying both perpetuals and subscriptions? Or do you think it was more coincidental to see both accelerating at the same time?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't -- now I'm speaking a little out of school. We got to d a little bit more work on this. but I don't think it was customer's buying both. That's just a little bit of an awkward purchase. I think it was the outreach from our channel partners created
componenttext: I don't -- now I'm speaking a little out of school. We got to d a little bit more work on this. but I don't think it was customer's buying both. That's just a little bit of an awkward purchase. I think it was the outreach from our channel partners created demand. And when people decided to buy, then they make that choice. But more likely is they chose one or the other, not both at this point.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Matt Hedberg from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Matt Hedberg from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, I've got a modeling question. Now that you're done with the license option for software, how should we think about the trajectory of the run rate of that license line going forward? I do think you allocate some of the subscription Seattleite cents.
componenttext: Scott, I've got a modeling question. Now that you're done with the license option for software, how should we think about the trajectory of the run rate of that license line going forward? I do think you allocate some of the subscription Seattleite cents. Is that correct?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: That is right, Matt. So if you look at that line there's 3 components to it. One is perpetual license sales that get immediately recognized and, of course, that piece go to 0. The second is that line is actually license and other, so there's some -- if th
componenttext: That is right, Matt. So if you look at that line there's 3 components to it. One is perpetual license sales that get immediately recognized and, of course, that piece go to 0. The second is that line is actually license and other, so there's some -- if there's a grab bag of smaller items in there, some legacy products that, little bit of consulting in there, so that piece we thought about that historically. If you go back a few quarters when we were selling perpetual licenses, that piece being about 10% of the total. That other piece will continue, the license  piece, the perpetual license piece goes to 0. The third piece is what you just said. Both the product subs and the EBAs, of course, when we sell it, goes immediately into deferred revenue and gets recognized ratably. But as it comes out of deferred, a portion of it -- because if you think of the term license, the customers buying 2 things, they're buying access to the license and they're buying maintenance, so a portion of a different revenue accretive back into the license line and a portion of that accretive back into the maintenance line. I know it's confusing. I would love to say that I'm changing that today. We are working on changing that so that it's much clearer for you to be able to see how subscription revenue comes back into a line called subscription. Maintenance is in the maintenance line. And then what's left is license and other really is mostly other at that point.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As I said, it's roughly 80% of the product subscription and 55% of the EBAs gets recorded as license revenue. So it's way more than, I think, many people have their models. And we're doing everything we can to change it and try to clarify it so that
componenttext: Yes. As I said, it's roughly 80% of the product subscription and 55% of the EBAs gets recorded as license revenue. So it's way more than, I think, many people have their models. And we're doing everything we can to change it and try to clarify it so that it's much paper in terms of what, I think, everyone would just essentially referred to as subscription. So we'll try to make this is there as possible, but hopefully, there's 2 pieces of data. It's a little bit easy for us to model what's going on.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Kash Rangan from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Kash Rangan from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wasn't sure if this question has been asked earlier, but, I guess, more of a question for Scott. What is your view on the new accounting standard that is been proposed by the fast [indiscernible]the being reviewed by the SEC? I think they call at the AO
componenttext: I wasn't sure if this question has been asked earlier, but, I guess, more of a question for Scott. What is your view on the new accounting standard that is been proposed by the fast [indiscernible]the being reviewed by the SEC? I think they call at the AOC 606 particularly applies to software companies that are trying to move into a more ratable model. How much of it applies to Autodesk? How much of it does not apply to Autodesk? Just curious about your thoughts.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Kash. It applies to everyone. It's not just Autodesk or non-Autodesk. IT applies to everyone selling software. What we've been doing on that front and that we've talked about this when you're in town a couple of months ago. We have been very activel
componenttext: Sure, Kash. It applies to everyone. It's not just Autodesk or non-Autodesk. IT applies to everyone selling software. What we've been doing on that front and that we've talked about this when you're in town a couple of months ago. We have been very actively engaged on this as we have done everything that we have to share of the ratable revenue model, the last thing I want is to have that shift back based on the new [indiscernible] guidelines. So our, I guess, our controller has actually been a part of the AICPA task force that's working on clarifying the guidelines for FASB on how that will work and if you think of a lot of our offerings, they're actually hybrid offerings. There's some term license in there, but there's a lot of cloud-based offering inside there. And so we're committed to continuing to maintain ratable revenue for our products sales for both the product subscription sales going forward. Obviously, cloud is pretty straightforward and for EBAs. And we're staying very actively in touch with the group as those rules get clarified.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And one follow-up, if I could, for Carl. And I apologize if this question has already been answered. If yes, you don't need to. Any impact -- [indiscernible] fiscal stimulus as the next [indiscernible] cycle brings that forward, do you there's any pent up
componenttext: And one follow-up, if I could, for Carl. And I apologize if this question has already been answered. If yes, you don't need to. Any impact -- [indiscernible] fiscal stimulus as the next [indiscernible] cycle brings that forward, do you there's any pent up demand for infrastructure both globally and in particularly in the United States that could help you guys?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Anything that's sort of a larger infrastructure and spend will be good. I would say just generally speaking, you look across industries right now, AEC seems strong in all the countries we talked about where the economies are good. Construction in the U.S.
componenttext: Anything that's sort of a larger infrastructure and spend will be good. I would say just generally speaking, you look across industries right now, AEC seems strong in all the countries we talked about where the economies are good. Construction in the U.S. is really strong and Northern and Central Europe is really healthy. I, mean if you through the political changes, there is more infrastructure spent. That would all be to the good side. We're not counting on it. You've heard that promise before, so it will certainly be to our advantage.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Monika Garg from Pacific Crest.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Monika Garg from Pacific Crest.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: First  one on the ARR. The ARR growth year was close to 10% while your long-term target is 24% CAGR, right? So this quarter, you had, of course, perpetual is impacting it, but for the next quarter, as you're not filling anymore perpetual licenses, so shou
componenttext: First  one on the ARR. The ARR growth year was close to 10% while your long-term target is 24% CAGR, right? So this quarter, you had, of course, perpetual is impacting it, but for the next quarter, as you're not filling anymore perpetual licenses, so should the ARR growth start spinning toward 24% [ph] CAGR that you've talked about?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: It will, Monica. That's not intended to be every single year and every single quarter will be 24% obviously. I know you know that. That's a CAGR over that time frame. You will see ARR growth rate accelerate in the second half of the year partly because yo
componenttext: It will, Monica. That's not intended to be every single year and every single quarter will be 24% obviously. I know you know that. That's a CAGR over that time frame. You will see ARR growth rate accelerate in the second half of the year partly because you see the divergence in the ARR growth rates between maintenance on a slight decline and new model growing 86% year-on-year a constant currency as new model becomes a bigger piece of the total, that drives it up. But also, as we go forward, there will be a higher and higher mix of the new model subs. And within that, the subscriptions growth that will continue to drive new model to a significant we higher level. So you will see that begin to accelerate in the second half and continue.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on the follow-up side, if you look at the revenue on the platform solution PSEB segment, that has come down Q-over-Q and  year-over-year. Is there any reclassification in that segment?
componenttext: So on the follow-up side, if you look at the revenue on the platform solution PSEB segment, that has come down Q-over-Q and  year-over-year. Is there any reclassification in that segment?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: There is. It's a continuation of what we've seen over the last several quarters, actually, since we launched suite 3 years ago, 3-plus years ago since we launched Suites, because what drives the vast majority of that PSEB segment is our CAD and LT. And of
componenttext: There is. It's a continuation of what we've seen over the last several quarters, actually, since we launched suite 3 years ago, 3-plus years ago since we launched Suites, because what drives the vast majority of that PSEB segment is our CAD and LT. And of course, AutoCAD is included in almost all of our -- in fact, it might be all of our Suites that gets sold. And so it's happening as it's not that there's less AutoCAD going out into the world. What's happening is that there's less of it being sold standalone and, therefore, dropping into that PSEB segment and more of it being sold as a component in a suite and in the future as a component Collections.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we have time for one more question today. Our final question comes from the line of Steve Koenig from Wedbush.
componenttext: And we have time for one more question today. Our final question comes from the line of Steve Koenig from Wedbush.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Apologize if this question has been an. I just want to maybe understand probably a little bit your thinking behind Collections and your design philosophy for it? And just, my background for this question was we were looking for an offering other than desk
componenttext: Apologize if this question has been an. I just want to maybe understand probably a little bit your thinking behind Collections and your design philosophy for it? And just, my background for this question was we were looking for an offering other than desktop subscription that might be a little bit more appropriate for the midmarket seeing some resistance in the midmarket to the subscriptions, more so than 4 or AutoCAD and guilty being sold as a PDF in the low end of the market. And yet Collections, it looks very much like the desktop subscription. It's a larger bundle and a slightly higher price point. Maybe the question, besides your kind of your intent behind it is what are the dividing line be in the market between your T-Flex and your EBAs versus Collections when it comes to consuming the Suites in terms of kind of companies side, is that how we should think about it? And what might that size be?

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the first thing I would say is so far, we gave a lot of proof points hopefully tonight. We haven't seen the resistance and as a matter of fact, much of -- many of the new products and desktop subscriptions for both Suites and Collections is being
componenttext: Yes. So the first thing I would say is so far, we gave a lot of proof points hopefully tonight. We haven't seen the resistance and as a matter of fact, much of -- many of the new products and desktop subscriptions for both Suites and Collections is being sold through our channel partners, which is serves the broadly speaking midmarket. So we think Collections are a nice way to both simplify and get people that easy ramp the deal cloud services. So what they're familiar with plus the new stuff. Let me jump to the other side of it is our EBAs -- and as you mentioned, the technology behind the T-Flex is really in the less than the top 1% of our accounts. So it has a lot of room to grow before these 2 things run into each other. And what I would add is I would expect to see more flexibility in our product offerings going forward. Collections it's really just a first step in the door of what we're going to do in terms of making sure the customers have more flexibility. And that's regardless of how would it will be sold. At the same time, we've documented and we've talked about how we really want to see our EBAs go out to a broader audience and how that will grow over time. So we think there's a lot of room between the 2 right now, and there's actually an opportunity to introduce other offerings that have that level of activity from T-Flex. For example, it can easily be sold by our channel partners.

headline: Autodesk, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 25, 2016

componenttext: And that concludes our question-and-answer session for today. I would like to turn the conference back over to Autodesk for any additional comments.
